Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XNG-RGM1-JCMN-Y2DF-00000-002:00PM Water Cooler 12/4/20192019-12-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis2:00PM Water Cooler 12/4/2019Lambert Strether

Dec 04, 2019( Naked Capitalism: http://www.nakedcapitalism.com/ Delivered by Newstex) By Lambert Strether of Corrente. Trade 'Falling impeachment support raises pressure for Democrats on trade' [The Hill[1]]. 'The drop in support for impeachment in the polls is increasing pressure on Democrats to strike a deal on the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). Polling on impeachment has found that a majority of respondents support the process, but support has dropped from key groups of independents as public hearings got underway. An Emerson poll in November found 43 percent of voters overall supporting impeachment compared with 45 percent opposed. That represented a 6-point swing from the pollster's survey in October.

If that trend continues as the inquiry heads to the House Judiciary Committee this week, Democrats could become more mindful of notching a major bipartisan accomplishment.' 'U.S., China Move Closer to Trade Deal Despite Harsh Rhetoric' [Bloomberg[2]]. 'The U.S. and China are moving closer to agreeing on the amount of tariffs that would be rolled back in a phase-one trade deal despite tensions over Hong Kong and Xinjiang, people familiar with the talks said. The people, who asked not to be identified, said that U.S. President Donald Trump's comments Tuesday downplaying the urgency of a deal shouldn't be understood to mean the talks were stalling, as he was speaking off the cuff. Recent U.S. legislation seeking to sanction Chinese officials over human-rights issues in Hong Kong and Xinjiang are unlikely to impact the talks, one person familiar with Beijing's thinking said. U.S. negotiators expect a phase-one deal with China to be completed before American tariffs are set to rise on Dec. 15, the people said. Outstanding issues in the talks include how to guarantee China's purchases of U.S. agricultural goods and exactly which duties to roll back, they added.' 'French exporters from the vineyards of Champagne to Chanel workshops are looking at their supply chains as a tariff dispute between the U.S. and France flares up. The magnitude of the proposed 100% tariffs on $2.4 billion in exports threatens to bite a luxury-goods industry that seemed relatively insulated from trade tensions' [Wall Street Journal[3]]. 'The dispute is rooted in questions over taxation of digital services from big tech companies Shifting their specialized production would be hard for many of the brands. Still, conglomerate LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton SE has three U.S. workshops and others outside France that could take on production to avoid the levies.' • See 'President Trump and Bernard Arnault of LVMH to Open New Louis Vuitton Factory in Texas[4].' 'Forget the paper trail — blockchain set to shake up trade finance' [Financial Times[5]]. 'On average, a cross-border transaction requires the exchange of 36 documents and 240 copies, says Kerstin Braun, president of Stenn Group, which provides trade finance. By 2050, experts suggest blockchain could provide a digital record of transactions. This would streamline the paper trail and improve transparency between parties, allowing the introduction of practices such as 'dynamic factoring', where interest rates change as goods approach their final destination.' •And then we could speculate on dynamic factoring! Anyhow, 2050? Politics 'But what is government itself, but the greatest of all reflections on human nature?' -James Madison, Federalist 51 'They had one weapon left and both knew it: treachery.' -Frank Herbert, DuneHere is a second counter for the Iowa Caucus, which is obviously just around the corner: * * *2020Alert reader dk (not to be confused with DK) is in the process of developing the following interactive chart. Here is (are) the latest Dem Primary Polling as of 12/4/2019, 12:00 PM EST. Biden leads, Sanders strong second, Warren five points back (!), Buttigeig trailing. The tiny YouGov poll follows big fat Morning Consult. This pattern seems temporarily stable. On to the next debate, and Iowa:Here is the latest, as of 12/4/2019, 12:00 PM EST:Changes: Harris out, Bloomberg in. Also, we can now show events (e.g., debate #3). UPDATE I think we have to track the polls because so much of the horse-race coverage is generated by them; and at least with these charts we're insulating ourselves against getting excited about any one poll. That said, we should remember that the polling in 2016, as it turned out, was more about narrative than about sampling, and that this year is, if anything, even more so. In fact, one is entitled to ask, with the latest Buttigieg boomlet (bubble? (bezzle?)) which came first: The narrative, or the poll? One hears of push polling, to be sure, but not of collective push polling by herding pollsters. We should also worry about state polls with very small sample sizes and big gaps in coverage. And that's before we get to the issues with cellphones (as well as whether voters in very small, very early states game their answers). So we are indeed following a horse-race, but the horses don't stay in their lanes, some of the horses are not in it to win but to interfere with the others, the track is very muddy, and the mud has splattered our binoculars, such that it's very hard to see what's going on from the stands. Also, the track owners are crooked and the stewards are on the take. Everything's fine. I think dk has started a really neat project, and in the near future we'll seek your feedback (within reason) for the tool 'live.'* * *Biden (D)(1): 'Biden says Buttigieg 'stole' his healthcare plan' [Reuters[6]] • Two rats fighting over the same stale slice of pizza. Biden (D)(2): Classy: Per Biden pool, one of the event co-hosts for the Manhattan fundraiser Biden attended at the home of a prominent art dealer joked 'Don't touch the Rothko!' Except I imagine it was probably not a joke because it was a real Rothko. — Lissandra Villa (@LissandraVilla) December 4, 2019[7]I'm not much of a Rothko fan, but even I wouldn't want Biden's latest gaffe to be putting an elbow through a large and expensive painting. UPDATE Bloomberg (D)(1): ' In Appeal to Hard Left, Bloomberg Praises Chinese Communism' [Eric Levitz, New York Magazine[8]]. The editor who wrote that headline needs to be spoken to. The 'hard left'? Who, exactly? Bob Avakian? Wu mao tankies? Levitz himself: 'it is remarkable how much the patron saint of neoliberal paternalism's views on China overlap with those of 'tankie' Twitter. It's hard to imagine that a figure like Sanders or Elizabeth Warren could have argued that Xi is not a dictator — and that the Chinese Communist Party is accountable to majoritarian opinion — without suffering broad bipartisan condemnation. Yet Bloomberg's remarks in September prompted few calumnious columns on the authoritarianism of the anti-populist center[9]. Which is unfortunate, since the U.S. business community's interests in Beijing make this political tendency a genuine threat[10] Donald Trump has tried to paint his Democratic opponents as cosseted coastal elites who are in bed with China, exert undue influence over the mainstream media, and want to tell working-class Americans how to live[11] [and die. -lambert]. If Democrats somehow nominate Bloomberg, Trump's ideal foil will be made of money instead of straw[12].' Buttigieg (D)(1): 'What's Really Behind Pete Buttigieg's Lack Of Support Among Black Voters?' [FiveThirtyEight[13]]. •This looks to me like a long list of rationalizations for Buttigieg's black support, which in my view boil down to (a) charitably, a tin ear for black concerns and worldview, and (b) bad and/or painful policy in the South Bend with the police, housing, and now desegration. 'These people all talk to each other,' you know. As for example: So I quote tweeted a video of Mayor Pete making a Birther joke in 2018. One of the defenses was that the video was taken out of context but here is a video of him making a different Birther joke for giggles in 2017. Here's the full video (joke @ 31:05)https://t.co/y4ySrTqPB4[14] — Zerlina Maxwell (@ZerlinaMaxwell) December 3, 2019[15]Buttigieg (D)(2): 'Pete Buttigieg's Willful Illusion' [New York Magazine[16]]. 'During a campaign stop in Goldsboro, North Carolina, Buttigieg admitted to Reverend William Barber that he'd underestimated how badly segregated schools still were in South Bend. 'I have to confess that I was slow to realize — I worked for years under the illusion that our schools in my city were integrated,' Buttigieg said. 'Because they had to be, because of a court order.'. For Buttigieg, knowing that segregation was still a problem wasn't just a matter of easily-ascertainable testimony provided in local newspapers and by any black parent whose child attended a local school. It was the subject of one of the city's longest-running civil-rights mandates, and thus an odd thing for its mayor to be unaware of, even if the schools weren't under his immediate purview. [A]s he spins his proclaimed ignorance into a self-deprecating campaign-trail story about personal growth, he's mystified the issue further by locating the problem far afield — in segregation patterns in the surrounding county; in desegregation processes he didn't realize were ongoing, despite their decades of continuous implementation.' • For years! (Does anybody know if the road to the South Bend airport passes through an obviously segregated neighborhood?) Sanders (D)(1): 'The case for Bernie Sanders' [Ryan Cooper, The Week[17]]. 'This brings me finally to theories of change. Either Sanders' or Warren's full agenda would be non-starters in the current Congress, and probably not much more likely after 2020 if current trends hold. Sanders argues that he can upturn the political landscape by activating the enormous population of disaffected non-voters, who are disproportionately non-white, young, and less educated, both to elect new representatives and senators and pressure existing ones. (And sure enough, his base of support is more rooted in these groups[18] than any other candidate.) This is the formula he followed as mayor of Burlington, which was a smashing success[19], though at an obviously far smaller scale. To be sure, this is a pretty optimistic idea. But it's also the only strategy even proposed that would change the political system fast enough to deal with the multiple crises bedeviling the United States — above all climate change.' Sanders (D)(2): Good crowd at Morehouse: [embedded content] It's an hour long. No doubt other campaigns are mining it for oppo as we speak. Warren (D)(1): 'Some Elizabeth Warren backers urge the 'plans' candidate to get more personal' [Boston Globe[20]]. 'As her standing in the polls slipped, Warren took the unusual step of shaking things up this week. At two campaign events in Iowa, she chopped her policy-dense stump speech by more than half and answered four times as many questions from voters than usual, allowing for more unplanned moments of levity and emotion.' And:Warren supporters in Iowa were delighted by a more personal exchange that unfolded Sunday in a windowless gymnasium in Marion, when a young voter with tears in her eyes asked Warren if there was a time when she was not accepted by someone she looked up to. Warren, who generally launches into her answers with an expression of joy ('Oh, that's fabulous!') and a policy prescription, gripped the microphone and paused to steady herself. 'My mother and I had very different views of how to build a future. She wanted me to marry well and I really tried and it just didn't work out,' Warren said, her voice seeming to [(!!)] break as she described calling her mother to tell her about her divorce in 1978. 'I heard the disappointment in her voice, I knew how she felt about it, but I also know it was the right thing to do,' Warren said. Then Warren and the voter embraced. As the video went viral, Warren's supporters hoped it signaled a new willingness by the candidate to move away from dense policy in favor of more humanizing exchanges that could help her with her next challenge: Getting more voters to like her enough to vote for her, even if they do not always agree with her. Lots to ponder here. First, note the lack of agency in 'the video went viral.' Warren personally tweeted it out! Second, Sanders embraces people on the trail too, generally after they've told some horror story about our horrific health care system. Emotion and policy are not in contradiction, as this article implies. Third, 'likeability.' Come on, man. Fourth, this is Warren's home town paper. Are we looking at staff panic, or jitters? (Again, how on earth could a competent staff have allowed Warren to tweet out her deeply sincere video personally, instead of having it spontaneously appear from a supporter? Is their online presence that weak?) UPDATE Yang (D)(1): 'Andrew Yang's Staff Pulls Him Back From Spraying Whipped Cream Into Mouths of Kneeling Supporters' [Rolling Stone[21]]. •Oh.* * *'Democrats value diversity, but the presidential field is increasingly white' [Los Angeles Times[22]]. ''No matter your candidate, you have to recognize that going from the most diverse field ever in January to a potentially all-white debate stage in December is catastrophic,' said Leah Greenberg, co-founder of Indivisible, a Democratic activist group. 'The implicit racism and sexism of 'electability' is deeply damaging to democracy.'' • Well This seems to be the line taken by the Harris campaign. To me, it looks like the Clintonites in Harris's campaign refusing to take responsibility for a loss. As usual.Realignment and Legitimacy'The Old Jewish World: From Leftists to Neocons toBernie Sanders' [Yasha Levine, Immigrants as a Weapon[23]]. 'Thinking back to my time [in liberal Bay Area circles] through the 1990s, I now realize that the general vibe of the Jewish-American community was very aggressively PMC — full of mildly apologetic Zionism, liberal interventionism, progressive neoliberalism. Everyone was either a corporate lawyer, a doctor, or worked in finance. As a fresh-off-the-Boeing immigrant with no historical roots here, I had no clue that another type of Jewish culture had existed in America not that long ago — a culture that actually fought power rather than accept establishment and big business dogma. I can't recall this history being taught in my Sherith Israel Jewish Sunday school classes. Or maybe it was taught but quickly and superficially, because it never lodged in my memory. And, anyway, why would my school focus on this history? For a totally integrated neoliberal Jewish community, that old Jewish leftwing world must have seemed quaint and kinda embarrassing — an anachronism that had no relevance to an America that had just triumphed over communism and socialism Actuallywhile writing this I just now realized there is another big echo of this failed leftwing Jewish world: Bernie Sanders. Guess that's why PMC Jewish-Americans hate him so much.' • Hah. 'Stacey Abrams Hires Palast Investigations Team for Massive Federal Suit to Restore Voting Rights' [Greg Palast[24]]. 'Stacey Abrams' non-profit Fair Fight has retained the Palast Investigations team experts to provide court testimony, based on our six years of investigation, in Fair Fight's federal law suit to overturn Georgia's massive, racially biased purge of voters.' • Good move by Abrams. Stats Watch ADP Employment Report, November 2019: Way below consensus [Econoday[25]]. • Prose snippets still the consensus outlook, even after the data is printed. May have to seek out a new source. Purchasing Managers Manufacturing Index, November 2019: Above consensus [Econoday[26]]. Purchasing Managers' Services Index, November 2019: Upper end of consensus [Econoday[27]]. Institute For Supply Management Non-Manufacturing Index, November 2019: Within consensus [Econoday[28]]. Shipping: 'The maritime world's big new clean-air deadline is arriving with clouds on the horizon. Authorities in Greece want the rule requiring a steep cutback in sulfur emissions to be pushed back [T]he opposition is significant because Greece is the world's biggest ship-owning nation, and because it raises doubts about the industry's ability to meet other ambitious targets in coming years' [Wall Street Journal[29]]. 'Shipping companies have taken different paths to cut sulfur emissions, with some opting for exhaust-cleaning scrubbers and others banking on new, more expensive fuel. Pushing back enforcement will leave carriers that acted to meet the deadline shouldering the cost burden and suggest that future goals could be more malleable.' • Ugh. Shipping: 'Swift confirms driver leader instructed truckers to drive in inclement weather' [Freight Waves[30]]. 'Some truck drivers for Swift Transportation, a unit of Knight-Swift Transportation Holdings Inc. (NYSE: KNX), said they received messages via their onboard computer messaging systems around 7 a.m. Dec. 2 instructing them to chain up and drive in inclement weather to get their loads delivered on time. Big Ag: 'Poor Potato Crops Could Lead to a North American French Fry Shortage' [Smithsonian[31]]. 'The trouble started in October, when cold and wet conditions left potato growing regions covered in frost. Farmers in Alberta and Ohio were able to salvage and store some of their crops, but farmers in other areas, like Manitoba, North Dakota and Minnesota, had no choice but to give up on their beleaguered potatoes. Back in November, the United States Department of Agriculture predicted[32] that production outputs from the country's top nine potato producing states will fall 6.1 percent in 2019. Crops were down three percent in the autumn season alone, which, according to the United Potato Growers of Canada[33], 'is one of the lowest crops on record.'' The Bezzle: 'Den Automation raised millions to 'reinvent' the light switch. Now it's lights out for startup' [The Register[34]]. 'Den Automation, the once-promising UK smart home startup that raised nearly 4.5m via equity crowdfunding and boasted former Amstrad chief Bob Watkins as CEO, has agreed to go into liquidation Den Automation was founded in 2014 by Yasser Khattak, a 17-year-old wunderkind from Maidstone, Kent, who came up with the idea for the business while studying for his A Levels. Khattak subsequently dropped out to focus on the business full time. The concept behind Den Automation was simple. It built 'smart' light switches and wall sockets that were visually indistinguishable from their 'dumb' equivalents and could be installed by a layman, rather than a trained electrician. Part of the problem is that hardware is well hard. Bringing any kind of physical product to market is difficult, as manufacturers have to wrestle with supply chain and certification issue. Den Automation was no exception. As the product neared its promised release date, it was beset with repeated delays. One delay, which added more than eight weeks to the company's delivery schedule, was to address a flaw that could potentially result in a fire hazard.' • Oops. But wait, there's more: 'After six uneventful months, things started to go sour. On 5 October, the company's servers were switched off without warning. This rendered all previously sold switches and sockets useless.' • The machine stops[35].* * *Today's Fear ...eed Index: 67 Greed (previous close: 63 Extreme Greed) [CNN[36]]. One week ago: 78 (Greed). (0 is Extreme Fear; 100 is Extreme Greed). Last updated Dec 4 at 11:59am. Bit of a rebound (toward Greed).The Biosphere 'The Hidden History of American Anti-Car Protests' [City Lab[37]]. 'But all over America in the 1950s and 1960s, residents, particularly women, organized demonstrations against car traffic—and their street protests often closely resembled the Dutch Stop de kindermoord protests that would come in the 1970s. They demanded slower driving, usually seeking stop signs, streetlights, or crossing guards. Some demanded pedestrian over- or underpasses. Most such demonstrations were in dense residential districts of large cities, but many occurred in small cities, suburbs, and towns. Though white women predominated in many or most such demonstrations, black and Hispanic people organized some and participated in many. Men participated too, though generally as a small minority of the total. The decline of the protests signaled the now-preferred path to traffic safety: parental chauffeuring and the abandonment of children's independent mobility. Many demonstrations—particularly the biggest ones—were triggered by the injury or death of a child.' • So, all those bikes in the Netherlands. Came from U.S. protests! 'The impact of high ambient temperatures on delivery timing and gestational lengths' [Nature[38]]. 'Evidence suggests that heat exposure increases delivery risk for pregnant women. Acceleration of childbirth leads to shorter gestation, which has been linked to later health and cognitive outcomes. Evidence suggests that heat exposure increases delivery risk for pregnant women. Acceleration of childbirth leads to shorter gestation, which has been linked to later health and cognitive outcomes.' Health Care 'State lawmakers acknowledge lobbyists helped craft their op-eds attacking Medicare-for-all' [WaPo[39]]. 'Lobbyists either helped draft or made extensive revisions to opinion columns published by three state lawmakers in a way that suggested Medicare-for-all and other government involvement in health care posed dangers, according to emails obtained by The Washington Post. Montana state Rep. Kathy Kelker (D) and Sen. Jen Gross (D) acknowledged in interviews that editorials they published separately about the single-payer health proposal included language provided by John MacDonald, a lobbyist and consultant in the state who disclosed in private emails that he worked for an unnamed client. Gross said MacDonald contacted her on behalf of the Partnership for America's Health Care Future, a multimillion-dollar industry group founded in 2018 and funded by hospitals, private insurers, drug companies and other private health-care firms.' •The vile, loathesome, and lethal Partnership for America's Health Care Future[40] is run, let us remember, by Lauren Crawford Shaver, says Politico: a former Obama health official who is now the Partnership's executive director and runs its day-to-day operations Oddly, or not, Politico omits Shaver's work[41] both the 2008 and 2016 Clinton campaigns. Never, ever. One might almost think liberal Democrats are why we can't have nice things. The Carceral State 'With Prison Staff Shortage, Oklahoma Looks to Hire Teenagers as Guards' [Oklahoma Watch[42]]. 'Teenagers, fresh out of high school, could be hired to guard and oversee hardened criminals in Oklahoma's chronically overcrowded and understaffed prisons. In a little-noticed action, the Oklahoma Board of Corrections passed a set of legislative requests earlier this month that include allowing prisons to hire corrections officials as young as 18. Currently the minimum age is 20. The Department of Correction has struggled for years to attract and retain workers for the job, which now starts with a salary of just under $33,000 a year.' • Let it never be said there are no jobs! The 420 'Feds clarify it's OK for banks to serve hemp companies; guidance could ease transactions for hundreds of Nevada hemp growers' [Nevada Independent[43]]. 'Federal regulators say banks should treat authorized hemp businesses the same as other legal companies, drawing cheers from Nevada cultivators who have faced strict scrutiny in their financial transactions because hemp's close cousin, marijuana, remains illegal at the federal level. Hemp is a variety of the cannabis plant used to create everything from textiles and paper to dietary supplements and CBD oil, but that unlike marijuana used as a drug, doesn't contain enough of the psychoactive substance THC to get a person high. It was legalized through the federal government's 2018 Farm Bill, but banks encountering hemp customers have continued to follow the protocols they use for marijuana companies, including reporting their activity to the federal government through suspicious activity reports (SARs) even if state law makes marijuana legal.' •Hemp not being the same as marijuana. So modified rapture. Thanksgiving Post Mortem They get letters: So last week for Thanksgiving I ran a headline saying 'Turducken Is Performative,' paraphrasing @kimseverson[44]. Over the weekend I got an email from JUDITH BUTLER pic.twitter.com/hgt9AYvM3y[45]; — Spencer BokatLindell (@bokatlindell) December 2, 2019[46]'Performative' has indeed come to mean ersatz, contra Butler, because politically empowered professional symbol manipulators have indeed confused words and deeds ('shifting the Overton Window'?).Groves of Academe 'The Growing Partisan Divide in Views of Higher Education' [Pew Research Center[47]]. 'A new Pew Research Center survey finds that only half of American adults think colleges and universities are having a positive effect on the way things are going in the country these days. About four-in-ten (38%) say they are having a negative impact - up from 26% in 2012. The share of Americans saying colleges and universities have a negative effect has increased by 12 percentage points since 2012. The increase in negative views has come almost entirely from Republicans and independents who lean Republican.' Class Warfare 'Modern Slavery' [Council on Foreign Relations[48]]. 'Slavery, long banned and universally condemned, persists in many corners of the world, victimizing tens of millions of people.' • Lots of good data here, including definitions of various kinds of slavery (e.g., bonded labor), but presented in a horrid mobile- and swipe-friendly format that is very hard to read on a productivity tool, like a laptop or desktop. News of the Wired 'Towards a comparative science of emotion: Affect and consciousness in humans and animals' [Science Direct[49]]. 'In posing questions about conscious affect in animals, much (though not all) work starts with the human case, where understanding is facilitated by subjects' emotional reports (as well as the informal introspection the researcher employs in interpreting such reports). The human models are then used to identify candidate criteria for conscious emotion, which can be applied to observations of brain, behaviour, and physiology in different animal species.' • That's the best nugget I can find in this review of the literature. 'A Genetic Model of the Connectome' [Neuron[50]]. From the abstract: 'The connectomes of organisms of the same species show remarkable architectural and often local wiring similarity, raising the question: where and how is neuronal connectivity encoded?' •Beyond the first sentence, I get a little lost, but word of the day: Connectome. 'Trailblazing Star Trek Writer D.C. Fontana Dies at 80: 'She Was a Pioneer'' [MSN[51]]. 'Not only was Fontana responsible for creating much of Star Trek canon, she also 'helped blaze a trail for female writers in sci-fi television,' the official website said in its obituary. 'Fontana's credits to Star Trek cannot be understated, both as a writer of great stories and as a trailblazer for other women.'' • Lots of good detail here. 'The Dead ...mpany Edition' [Why is this interesting?[52]]. 'John Mayer, he of the voluminous Instagram comments, has been sharing the stage with a unit comprised of three of the original members of the Grateful Dead (Bob Weir, Bill Kreutzmann and Mickey Hart), as well as a handful of other sidemen What's fascinating about this particular incarnation of the Dead is that after any number of attempts to fill Jerry Garcia's shoes, this one is sticking. From Furthur to the Other Ones, and Phil Lesh and Friends to the Fare Thee Well Shows in Chicago with Trey Anastasio, the other post-Garcia line-ups paid service to the music but did not inhabit it as this current grouping does. The root of the Grateful Dead has always been an all-hands on deck allegiance to the great God of improvisation, and Mayer's managed to become the straw that stirs the drink in this latter-day configuration. Mayer's blues idiom is one of the reasons the band sounds fresh, as the other stand-ins for Garcia came from a rock and roll background where Mayer, for all of his flaws, is steeped in the blues, like original vocalist McKernan. Something about it works particularly well with the band's signature blend of psychedelia, country, and improvisation breathes new life into each song in ways both surprising and uniquely satisfying By recreating the psychic improvisational synergy of the earliest Dead shows with this line-up, the love affair between audience and band has been rekindled and while there are criticisms that the band is slow, their ability to dive into the layered architectural nature of the music is at this point revered.' •As a former Deadhead, I am here for the focus on improvisation, while questioning whether any unit without Phil Lesh can be called an 'incarnation of the Dead.'* * *Readers, feel free to contact me at lambert [UNDERSCORE] strether [DOT] corrente [AT] yahoo [DOT] com, with (a) links, and even better (b) sources I should curate regularly, (c) how to send me a check if you are allergic to PayPal, and (d) to find out how to send me images of plants. Vegetables are fine! Fungi and coral are deemed to be honorary plants! If you want your handle to appear as a credit, please place it at the start of your mail in parentheses: (thus). Otherwise, I will anonymize by using your initials. See the previous Water Cooler (with plant) here[53]. Today's plant (PLW):PM writes: 'Idylwood park, Redmond WA.'* * *Readers: Water Cooler is a standalone entity not covered by the annual NC fundraiser. So if you see a link you especially like, or an item you wouldn't see anywhere else, please do not hesitate to express your appreciation in tangible form. Remember, a tip jar is for tipping! Regular positive feedback both makes me feel good and lets me know I'm on the right track with coverage. When I get no donations for five or ten days I get worried. More tangibly, a constant trickle of donations helps me with expenses, and I factor in that trickle when setting fundraising goals: Here is the screen that will appear, which I have helpfully annotated.If you hate PayPal, you can email me at lambert [UNDERSCORE] strether [DOT] corrente [AT] yahoo [DOT] com, and I will give you directions on how to send a check. Thank you!   https://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2019/12/200pm-water-cooler-12-4-2019.html?utm_source=feedburner..._medium=feed..._campaign=Feed:+NakedCapitalism+%28naked+capitalism%29# ;This entry was posted in Guest Post[54], Water Cooler[55] on December 4, 2019[56] by Lambert Strether[57]. About Lambert StretherReaders, I have had a correspondent characterize my views as realistic cynical. Let me briefly explain them. I believe in universal programs that provide concrete material benefits, especially to the working class. Medicare for All is the prime example, but tuition-free college and a Post Office Bank also fall under this heading. So do a Jobs Guarantee and a Debt Jubilee. Clearly, neither liberal Democrats nor conservative Republicans can deliver on such programs, because the two are different flavors of neoliberalism ('Because markets'). I don't much care about the 'ism' that delivers the benefits, although whichever one does have to put common humanity first, as opposed to markets. Could be a second FDR saving capitalism, democratic socialism leashing and collaring it, or communism razing it. I don't much care, as long as the benefits are delivered. To me, the key issue — and this is why Medicare for All is always first with me — is the tens of thousands of excess 'deaths from despair,' as described by the Case-Deaton study, and other recent studies. That enormous body count makes Medicare for All, at the very least, a moral and strategic imperative. And that level of suffering and organic damage makes the concerns of identity politics — even the worthy fight to help the refugees Bush, Obama, and Clinton's wars created — bright shiny objects by comparison. Hence my frustration with the news flow — currently in my view the swirling intersection of two, separate Shock Doctrine campaigns, one by the Administration, and the other by out-of-power liberals and their allies in the State and in the press — a news flow that constantly forces me to focus on matters that I regard as of secondary importance to the excess deaths. What kind of political economy is it that halts or even reverses the increases in life expectancy that civilized societies have achieved? I am also very hopeful that the continuing destruction of both party establishments will open the space for voices supporting programs similar to those I have listed; let's call such voices 'the left.' Volatility creates opportunity, especially if the Democrat establishment, which puts markets first and opposes all such programs, isn't allowed to get back into the saddle. Eyes on the prize! I love the tactical level, and secretly love even the horse race, since I've been blogging about it daily for fourteen years, but everything I write has this perspective at the back of it. urn:contentItem:5Y7X-H6V1-F03R-N09G-00000-0002/19 Links Pt2: The UN Should Be Ashamed of Its Anti-Israel Boycott List; The Only Way to Fight Anti-Semitism Is through Policy Action, Not with Lip Service2020-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis02/19 Links Pt2: The UN Should Be Ashamed of Its Anti-Israel Boycott List; The Only Way to Fight Anti-Semitism Is through Policy Action, Not with Lip ServiceIan

Feb 19, 2020( Elder of Ziyon: http://elderofziyon.blogspot.com Delivered by Newstex) From Ian:The UN Should Be Ashamed of Its Anti-Israel Boycott List[1] The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) has produced a handy catalogue of companies that supporters of Israel can give their business to. Of course, this was not its intention. The roster was compiled at the request of the UN Human Rights Council. This is a body in which countries whose idea of human rights is gender-neutral torture and equal-opportunity ballot-rigging get together and pass reams of vexatious resolutions against Israel.The BDS movement's economic warfare against the Jewish state has had little success but that's not the point: a UN body is tacitly legitimizing its agenda and even doing the research for it.

What OHCHR's list is about is the UN's institutional hostility towards Israel and support for "de-judaizing" Jerusalem and Judea and Samaria.Jerusalem is Israel's capital; before that it was the capital of the ancient Kingdom of Judah. However hard the UN strives to erase the Jewish character of the city, its historical record isn't going anywhere. When Israel captured Judea and Samaria in 1967, they did so not from any state called Palestine (no such state has ever existed), but from Jordan, whose annexation was almost universally unrecognized - it was an illegal occupation - and prior to this these lands had been part of Mandatory Palestine.Mandatory Palestine was created by the League of Nations to "secure the establishment of the Jewish national home." The Israelis have many innovations to their name, but perhaps their greatest feat is being the first nation-state in history to "illegally occupy" their own territory.The people the UN harms when it works to isolate and delegitimize Israel are the Palestinians. It tells them that their long, painful campaign of national self-harm is just and holds out false hope that it will one day triumph. It won't.The priority of anyone who professes to be pro-Palestinian should be convincing the Palestinians to recognize that Israel is here to stay and, on that basis, finally accept offers of peace and statehood. The Australian Editorial: A Brazen Anti-Semitic "Blacklist"[2] The UN Human Rights Council's "blacklist" of 112 international and local companies operating in the territories is a shameful attempt to strike a blow against the Middle East's only functioning democracy and upholder of the rule of law and religious freedom. No wonder Australia/Israel ...wish Affairs Council executive director Colin Rubenstein described publication of the blacklist as "a witch-hunt that reminds us of Nazi-era boycotts of the Jewish people." There is no precedent for any UN body taking similar action over a disputed territory, and no basis in international law for it to do so.As Dr. Rubenstein pointed out, it is not in breach of international law for the 112 companies to operate in the West Bank and east Jerusalem. "They are legitimate businesses providing goods and services...they are not breaking any international laws." Australia must waste no opportunity to condemn and counter the council's brazen hypocrisy and the sinister witch-hunt it has embarked on. https://www.jpost.com/HttpHandlers/ShowImage.ashx?id=383253...98...28 Against (Honest Discussions of) Anti-Semitism[3] Last October, protesters from the anti-Israel group, Students for Justice in Palestine, disrupted a panel on anti-Semitism hosted by Bard's Hannah Arendt Center. The disruptors thought it appropriate to single out an all-Jewish panel focused on hatred of Jews to vent their spleen at Israel. According to Batya Ungar Sargon of the Forward, who served on the panel, the protesters were even applauded by some of the invited conference attendees. These 'vaunted intellectuals, flown in from across the country to discuss racism, were commending a display of racism against Jews.'Racism against Jews? Perish the thought, replied distinguished defenders of the protest. These students weren't saying that the Jews, alone among peoples, should be hounded when they discuss threats to their safety. No, they were there mainly to protest the distinguished scholar of Yiddish literature and Jewish history, Ruth Wisse, who is, after all, some kind of conservative. Moreover, Wisse had made an imprecise remark about the exploitation of Palestinian suffering decades ago, and that, her critics maintain, suffices as evidence of anti-Palestinian racism. Finally, Wisse's talk on the panel focused on left-wing anti-Semitism, so why shouldn't Students for Justice in Palestine protest? Case closed. spies of no country adYes, as Ungar-Sargon reported, one of the protesters said that the Israel issue is inextricably bound to the question of anti-Semitism—that is, the protest could properly have taken place against any panel on anti-Semitism. Of course, the pro-Palestinian left doesn't just go around targeting anti-Semitism panels. Don't be ridiculous!Not so. Last Thursday, Deborah Lipstadt, gave a talk on anti-Semitism at the University of California, Berkeley, School of Law. Lipstadt, a distinguished scholar of modern Jewish history and author of the 2019 book, Antisemitism: Here and Now, is not a conservative. urn:contentItem:5WKM-KN21-F03R-N169-00000-002 days after an Instagram star's brutal killing went viral, YouTube is still hosting images of her body (GOOG, GOOGL)2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis2 days after an Instagram star's brutal killing went viral, YouTube is still hosting images of her body (GOOG, GOOGL)Jake Kanter

Jul 17, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) City of Utica Police The brutal killing of Bianca Devins[1], an Instagram star with thousands of followers, went viral on Monday after images of the crime were posted on the social network by the man charged with killing the 17-year-old. Instagram struggled to cope with the photos being republished by others, and two days on, YouTube was still featuring images of Devins' body in search results. Business Insider identified five videos that used a photo of the crime in the thumbnail.

Together, they have racked up more than 200,000 views. A spokesperson for YouTube did not respond to a request for comment. Facebook said it was "taking every measure to remove this content from our platforms." Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[2] Two days after the killing of an Instagram star with thousands of followers shocked the internet, YouTube has failed to remove multiple videos featuring images of her mutilated body from the platform. Bianca Devins, 17, was killed in the early hours of Sunday morning in the city of Utica, New York. Police have charged Brandon Clark, 21, with killing Devins. The incident made headlines around the world after Clark posted photos of Devins' body on his Instagram profile. Business Insider has seen the images and police have verified their authenticity. They were removed from Clark's Instagram Stories by Monday morning and some hours later, his account and his Facebook profile were deleted. But this was not before other Instagram users republished the photos. Read more: 'When I close my eyes, those images haunt me': Step mom of murdered teen social media influencer speaks out after photos of the crime spread online[3] Clark also shared the images on gaming chat service Discord, police said, while they have appeared on other social networks, including Twitter, where a simple search for Clark or Devins' name produced results with the photos on Monday. Instagram is reportedly getting a handle on the spread of the pictures[4], while users have also assisted in scrubbing them from the social network by flooding key hashtags with images of pink clouds.[5] Instagram has also shut down accounts impersonating Clark, it said, and blocked the hashtag #yesjuliet, which was his Instagram handle.YouTube features images of Devins' body in search resultsLittle has been said about YouTube, however, where videos containing the images remained on Wednesday, two days after the story went viral.Business Insider conducted incognito YouTube searches for "Bianca Devins" on Tuesday and Wednesday, and found five videos featuring images of Devins' body within the top search results. Four of the videos featured the photos in the thumbnail, but not within the content of the video — a tactic that could be used to increase engagement. Together, they racked up more than 181,000 views. The fifth video features a teenage boy commenting on Devins' death. An image of the crime is contained in the thumbnail and it also flashes up on screen during the video. It has more than 60,000 views and features a warning that it may be "inappropriate" for some users. Some of the videos were removed after Business Insider flagged them to YouTube. A YouTube spokesperson did not respond to a request for comment. It brings into sharp focus YouTube and Facebook-owned Instagram's continued failure to rid their platforms of harmful content. They have made repeated promises to improve their moderation processes, but frailties in their systems were exposed after a video of the New Zealand mosque massacre went viral in March. A Facebook spokesman said: "Our thoughts go out to those affected by this tragic event. We are taking every measure to remove this content from our platforms. Our goal is to take action as soon as possible — there is always room for improvement. We don't want people seeing content that violates our policies."Devins' mother calls for a message of loveIn a new statement released to the press on Wednesday, Devins' mother said she was devastated by her daughter's death. She added that she wanted to spread Devins' message of love. "While I could not be there to protect her from this violent end, I will now be her voice and spread the message of 'love, not violence'. Let us all pledge to share Bianca's amazing spirit to make this world a better place," she said.See Also: Everyone from Drake to the Jonas Brothers is posting photos where they look old — these are the best ones[6]Facebook, Google, Amazon, and Apple are testifying today about antitrust concerns as the battle cry to break up 'big tech' gets louder than ever[7]Facebook and Instagram are suffering from far more downtime than rival social networks[8] SEE ALSO:#RIPBianca: A 17-year-old social media star was found dead, and photos of the crime were posted online[9] [ 1]: Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. The bears have gone global it is an ugly start to the week for the markets this morning we are looking at the market near the lows of the morning, what we had been down almost 300 earlier Dow Industrials expected to be down 250 points right out of the gate this morning. I'm noticing the premarket this morning, Apple is below 160, Microsoft has threatened to go below 90, Facebook is below 190, Amazon is close to dropping below 1400. So, there's a lot of pressure on them but I want to pick up on your conversation just a couple seconds ago. How many times, Maria, have we said that future profits are the bedrock of today's stock prices? I mean, we say it all the time and I think that's accurate, profitability of American corporations dictates their stock price. But if we're looking at significant increases in profits down the road because of tax reform and for whatever reason a growing economy, why would the market tank right now? And surely that extra profitability down the road would limit today's losses or this week's losses or last week's losses. I would have thought that the expectation of profit will narrow the loss that we're now in. That's my point.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I think you make a good point because we are talking about what, 23 percent earnings growth in 2018, Stu. These are really good numbers. And I'm really -- Dagen just talk about Jeff Gundlach, very high profile, mutual fund manager who's talking about seven percent nominal growth. Seven percent in the first quarter, Stu.

VARNEY: Well, I heard the Atlanta Fed talk five percent growth which is a knockout, seven percent is truly stunning but in that environment of growth and profitability I think the loss will be limited, that's my point.

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes. Backdrop is pretty strong.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Those profits are worthless though, Stuart if interest rates are a lot higher, that's the issue playgrounds the stock market.

VAUSE: I take your point, but again, I think the loss will be limited but far for me to predict the stock market.

BARTIROMO: Stu, I'm looking forward to joining you in the next hour.

VAUSE: Yes. Good stuff.

BARTIROMO: I will see you soon. Stu, thanks so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour 9:00 a.m. Eastern. We're going to talk with the CEO and President of Wells Fargo in an exclusive interview right after this short break. .

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The shackles on Wells Fargo, the Federal Reserve has slapped Wells Fargo with an unprecedented punishment for years of misconduct including the creation of millions fake user accounts. The punishment imposed on Janet Yellen's last day as chiarman of the Fed will restrict growth at Wells to under $2 trillion in assets. Pressure the removal of four Wells Fargo board members and require the submission of detailed plans to remedy Wells Fargo's wrongdoing. Joining me right now in an exclusive interview is Wells Fargo and company CEO and President, Tim Sloan. Tim, thanks very much for joining us this morning. We appreciate your time.

TIM SLOAN, CEO, WELLS FARGO: Oh, you're welcome, Maria. It's great to see you and be with your viewers.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Your reaction to what the Fed instituted on Friday?

SLOAN: Sure. Maria, there is no doubt it was a disappointment. But I think the important point is that we've been making fundamental changes at Wells Fargo since I became CEO about 16 months ago. We've addressed leadership concerns, we've made fundamental changes in terms of how we're organized, we've invested billions of dollars in improving risk management practices. We have addressed any concerns that customers have including remediating customers who were impacted by the retail sales practices issue. And so, that the issue is that the Fed called out in order, our items that we are in midst of correcting anyway, and we have been for months. And in fact, in the order itself, the Fed highlighted the changes that the board has made as well as the changes that management has made to -- make Wells Fargo a better company and address these issues.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and you have announced a lot of the changes that you have been putting in place, over the last year, but given the fact that your asset size is dependent on the positive growth and if your growing deposits by what 4.6 percent a year or so. This consent order is going to force to you shrink your business, right? I mean, (INAUDIBLE) forced you to shrink some businesses in order to keep your assets flat so where do the -- which areas are you going to shrink?

SLOAN: Well, first and foremost, Maria, Wells Fargo is absolutely open for business. We can operate our company, serve our customers, with the $2- trillion balance sheet that you referred to. There are some areas, where we've outgrown our balance sheet because there have been opportunities created from some of our competitors. We will be reducing some non- operational deposits, we'll reduce some short-term investments, we'll reduce some deposits that we get from other banks, but overall, the order allows to us operate the company in a make-sense way so that we can continue to grow loans, Maria, as you know, we're the largest lender in this country, and being able to provide credit to our customers is not only critical for them but critical for economic growth, and then we'll continue to be able to take deposits from most of our customers.

BARTIROMO: Well, this morning, we're seeing a lot of your analysts react on Wall Street, everybody is downgrading the stocks, several downgrades on Wells Fargo shares, and obviously, the stock is down two percent right now, Tim. I mean, isn't it true as one analyst write, the operating leverage story is now delayed. The fact that now you are getting a restriction to growth just at the same time that we're actually seeing growth expand in the U.S. You're not going to be able to take advantage of that broader growth because you've got a restriction on growth.

SLOAN: No, Maria, I would push back on that. Again, Wells Fargo is open for business, we will be able to grow loans we will be able to grow deposits and serve our customers. It restricts our balance sheet growth but it doesn't restrict our ability to serve almost all of our consumers, that's what I communicated to our team on Friday and I'll re-communicate that to them again today. I want them out there serving our customers and being part of the continued economic growth of this country.

BARTIROMO: Sure, of course, but I'm just saying that it's unlikely that you can take full advantage of the economic growth story that is at your -- at your request fingertips here, even though you have got a risk you have terrific cash flow, significant excess capital position. You've got a risk here because you've got to limit growth, do you think this punishment was too severe?

SLOAN: You know, Maria, let me get back to your last question and then I'll answer that one. We were very clear on our call with our analyst investors on Friday that we think that net income after tax impact of the restriction of balance sheet growth this year will be $300 million to $400d million. We expect to have this cap lifted because, again, all the activities that the Fed would like us to improve on are the same ones that we like to improve on, and we believe that, well, it's likely that the asset cap could get lifted by the end of the year. So, we think the earnings impact is primarily focused now.

Again, to get back to your point about taking part in economic growth, you know, since the beginning of the year, we've seen an increase in our loan pipelines, and our expectations is that we'll be able to take a part in that economic growth. Again, there's no restriction on growing loans.

BARTIROMO: Right.

SLOAN: There's no restriction on providing credit, there's no restrictions on growing retail deposits, and so, we'll continue to do that.

BARTIROMO: So, will -- so will you have to shrink the trading and financial -- and the financial franchise to make room for more loans?

SLOAN: Maria, we have access liquidity at the company -- what we talked about on Friday, and provided a fair amount of detail in the deck that we provided to investors and analysts is that the three areas that will be focused on, making sure that we manage appropriately to get -- to stay below the cap; are one, non-operational deposits; two, deposits that we received from some financial institutions; and three, our short-term investments. That will allow us ample room to be able to grow, loans, serve customers, and grow deposits.

BARTIROMO: Now, you said that this is obviously going to start being in the rear-view mirror at some point. You said perhaps at the end of the year. What gives you that indication that this is going to be no longer a problem by year-end?

SLOAN: Well, again, it's my hope that that's -- and my expectation that that will be the case. And I say that for two reasons, Maria. First, in the order is very specific -- there's a very specific timeframe by which we're going to provide two different plans, to the Fed, the Federal Reserve, will review those plans, we'll bring a third party in to make sure that all the changes that we have been making and will make have been implemented and adopted within the company. That -- the next report by the third party is due by the end of September. And my expectation is that we'll meet and exceed the expectations of the Fed. And again, I think it's reasonable to assume that the cap could be lifted by year-end.

BARTIROMO: But the cap could be lifted by year-end. Let me ask you this, have you done work in terms of replacing these four board members? You've already said that you put plans in place in terms of new board members, and you've made those announcements publicly. What else -- what other changes are on the horizon in terms of these board members?

SLOAN: Yes, Maria, it's a really good question and observation. I think that the reporting related to these board members was mischaracterized. And, in fact, I know the Fed has been out speaking with the media to correct any mischaracterization that occurred on Friday. Our board has been making fundamental changes in terms of its governance, in terms of its oversight and refreshing board members over the last year. We've brought on six incredibly talented new board members since in the last year. We also brought in Mary Joe White, the former chair of SEC to assist in our board review and governance. So, we've made a lot of fundamental changes and we'll continue to listen to our shareholders as well as other stakeholders in terms of other changes that the board needs to make.

BARTIROMO: You know, we've been talking largely about the broader environment for financials, given the fact that interest rates are starting to go up, and net interest margins you expect to be -- to be a positive rather than a headwind going forward. Also, the backdrop of economic growth, and a rollback in regulations. But it seems, Tim, that Wells Fargo is not going to be able to really participate in a lot of the positives happenings for the broader averages and the broader banking sector because of these restrictions. So, I ask you again, do you see this as too strict? I mean, isn't this handicapping you?

SLOAN: Maria, there's no question that it's a disappointment. But, again, just to politely push back, Wells Fargo is open for business. We have 260,000 of the best team members in the industry that serve our customers every day. We will participate in the economic growth of the country, we'll participate and be a part of the economic growth of our customers. We're the largest mortgage lender in this country, we're the largest agricultural lender, we're the largest small business lender. We just did a survey of our small businesses along with Gallup, and they're as optimistic as they've been in over a decade, so we'll be able to participate in the growth. It's just that we're going to do that in a way that we maintain a level of as of 12:31 of our balance sheet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But the Federal Reserve is basically saying we're not changing this decree until we absolutely see evidence of change in terms of mentality at the bank and the change in terms of consumer protection. So, what specifically are you going to go back to the Federal Reserve to say, here's what we've changed, and we're ready for this decree to be lifted, whether it's at the end of this year or next year or whenever it is, you are going to have to provide evidence that, in fact, there are changes, what is that evidence that you see presenting?

SLOAN: Oh, sure. I mean, Maria, let's be specific about the order. The order asks for two plans, one, to see continued improvements in government oversight at the board level. That's easy to do because we've already been on that journey as I just mentioned. In terms of change -- or the plan that management is going to provide, they want to see our focus on a compliance plan and an operational plan. We've been well on our way for months, if not, more than a year, in terms of improvements in both compliance and operational risk management. So, it's not as if we're starting from a standing start, we've been working on all these areas now for the last few months if not the last year. And so, that's why I am confident we'll be able to meet and exceed the Fed's expectations.

BARTIROMO: Are you expected to sell divisions to pair back on certain divisions like the trading business given the fact that you are needing to stay under this cap of $1.95 trillion in assets, Tim?

SLOAN: No, not at all. There's -- there are no requirements in the -- in the consent order for any asset divestitures. Now having said that, we've been on a journey over the last couple of years to make sure that we've got the right businesses serving our customers. And so, we sold our crop insurance business a year ago. We sold our shareholder services business, in fact, we just announced that last week, we sold our commercial insurance brokers business. And so, there have been a number of businesses that we've decided are better in the hands of others, and we can return more -- it allows us to return more capital to our shareholders. That's an ongoing review at Wells Fargo that has nothing to do with this consent order. And we have no plans to exit any of our investment banking or trading activities.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you, Tim, you need to gain back the trust of Wells Fargo clients, we know that, and the Federal Reserve is calling this and that is quote, widespread consumer abuses and compliance break down. How did we get here, Tim? How did that happen?

SLOAN: Well, Maria, I think it's important to note that there's nothing new in the order. And so, it's bad comment --

BARTIROMO: No, it's widespread consumer abuses, compliance breakdowns. All I'm asking is how did you get here? What do you think as you look back? And I know that you came in, they put you in charge to fix this situation, but how did this happen, a widespread consumer abuse and compliance breakdown?

SLOAN: Maria, you're absolutely right. We've been making fundamental changes since I became CEO in October of 2016. There's no question that we made some mistakes, we've taken responsibility for that in terms of our retail banking business. What have we done to change that? We ended the retail banking incentive plan. We've got a new plan in place, it's working extremely well. Customers appreciate the change. The reaction from customers today and a retail banking business measured by customer loyalty and customer service has been -- has really been increasing, again, I think, in order there is nothing new that the Fed found. They were talking about history. We agreed that we made mistakes, we're fixing those mistakes or we fixed them.

BARTIROMO: But today, the market is reacting to the impact on your business. The fact that the rest of the industry is going to be growing, taking advantage of increasing growth numbers in the economy and you will be limited in terms of doing that. That's what all the analysts and the market is reacting to today. Tim, your stock is now down eight percent.

SLOAN: Maria, again, right, Wells Fargo is open for business. We will be able to continue to grow loans. We're -- again, we're the largest lender in the country and we're going to continue to be able to grow deposits for almost all of customers. We just need to be able to do that under a balance sheet cap. Many of our competitors over the last few years have shrunk their balance sheets and still been able to grow. And we expect to be able to serve our customers. Again, we're open for business.

BARTIROMO: So, you think -- you think that further focus on compliance and on customers obviously widespread consumer abuses and compliance breakdown as how the Fed said it, you think you will be able to grow going forward and really focus on that loan business as a result, even though you've got these limitations to grow with the asset size?

SLOAN: Absolutely. But, Maria, that doesn't take away from the fact that we are focused on improving risk management at Wells Fargo. We believe and we've demonstrated that we can do both at the same time. You've seen the progress over the last year that we've been able to make. You and I have talked about it on a few occasions. And again, I'm confident in our team, I'm confident in our business model and I'm confident we're going to be able to serve our customers even with the asset cap limitation that we have.

BARTIROMO: Yes. This is really a rare decree by the Fed, Tim, were you surprised?

SLOAN: Well, I was disappointed, for certain. I mean, the Fed had been public about the fact that they've been looking at how to resolve their concerns about Wells Fargo. This is the resolution of those concerns, there's no disagreement between ourselves and the Fed in terms of what we need to do to improve; we will make those improvements in risk management; we have been making those improvements.

BARTIROMO: Sure. In 17 months you have. Tim, good to see you, thanks very much for joining us this morning. Tim Sloan there.

SLOAN: Thank you, Maria. It's a --

BARTIROMO: Sending right over to "VARNEY & COMPANY" and Stuart. Stu, over to you.

END

Extracts.SummaryText: ... coming up, Tim Sloan. But we want to show you what's going on in market first because now big technology is also taking a beating coming after the market had that worst week in two years, last week. Joining us now to weigh in is the host of " VARNEY & COMPANY " Stuart Varney. Stu, good morning to you. STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria. You mentioned big tech and I, you know, like you, I follow very, very closely. I'm noticing the premarket this morning, Apple is ...

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RK7-8SW1-DXH2-62BN-00000-002 Killed, 116 Hurt When Amtrak Train Crashes Into Stationary Freight Train; Philadelphia Eagles Beat New England Patriots In Thriller As Phenomenal Nick Foles named MVP; Early Facebook And Google Employees Form Coalition To Fight What They Built2018-02-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLee Carter, Jeremy Ring, Tim SloanNEWSFinancial020503cb.2312 Killed, 116 Hurt When Amtrak Train Crashes Into Stationary Freight Train; Philadelphia Eagles Beat New England Patriots In Thriller As Phenomenal Nick Foles named MVP; Early Facebook And Google Employees Form Coalition To Fight What They BuiltMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Connell McShane, Blake Burman, Lauren Simonetti, Cheryl Casone, John Ratcliffe, Stuart Varney

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday February 5th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. The bears have gone global it is an ugly start to the week for the markets this morning we are looking at the market near the lows of the morning, what we had been down almost 300 earlier Dow Industrials expected to be down 250 points right out of the gate this morning. Inflation fears have taken a hold, interest rates moving higher, worries at a booming economy will lead to inflation and higher rates Friday marks the biggest one day decline for the Dow since the Brexit vote back in June of 2016, it was down 265 points on Friday ending of the lows of recession with a 2-1/2 percent sell-off. The S&P 500 and NASDAQ weaker down two percent, overseas investors took a queue from the U.S.

In Europe this morning, we have got a sell-off there as well FT 100 down 1- 1/3 percent, the CAC Quarante down 1-1/2 percent and the DAX Index down almost one percent. Economic data also coming out in Europe this morning as is the case in China, we have the (INAUDIBLE) survey overnight and that was one help to the markets in China that's why the Shanghai composite was up overnight by three quarters of a percent but the rest of the markets in Asia down and down sharply. Nikkei Average in Japan hard as hit down 2-1/2 percent. Passing the torch the Janet Yellen era has come to a close as Jay Powell prepares for first day as Chairman of the Federal Reserve today. The challenges that lie ahead for Powell as he takes the rein at the Federal Reserve plus Yellen's parting shot for Wells Fargo look at this, the Fed taking unprecedented action by slapping sanctions against the bank. I will talk with the President and CEO of Wells Fargo this morning, Tim Sloan will join me to react to this new strict, rare rules coming from the Fed on Wells Fargo. And then a Super Bowl stunner, the Eagles soaring past the Patriots to take their first ever title.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Philadelphia Eagles, the long drought is over.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Philadelphia erupted in celebration after the victory, thousands of fans taking to the streets in rivalry and in true Philly fashion, got a little rowdy as well live. We're taking it live with the highlights from the big game, coming up and the highly anticipated halftime show as well. All those stories coming up this Monday morning and join me to break it all down Fox Business Network, it's Dagen McDowell and Connell McShane, along the Pollster and President of Manslansky and Partners, Lee Carter. Great to see you.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY AND PARTNERS: It's great to be here.

BARTIROMO: A lot of happening this morning.

CONNELL MCSHANE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh yes, see all these markets fair. So we're down 250 or so it would be interesting today.

MCDOWELL: No, I was just -- a while I was looking down it was because I was actually doing research on the markets and with a new Federal Reserve Chief coming in to office that you've seen market declines when Volcker took off as when Greenspan took off as when Bernanke as -- and even a slight decline when Janet Yellen took office and so it's the unknown of what is this person going to do in terms of monetary policy.

BARTIROMO: Some people want to see as they call it like a whole vomiting out I mean they want to see the markets sell off a lot. I knew some conversation this morning on trading desks (INAUDIBLE) I hope it doesn't open down a fraction, I hope it doesn't -- you know improve by the close. I want to see a cleanout like we saw on Friday, what do you think?

MCDOWELL: I think that they would rather wash out rapidly than just kind of be this long drawn-out decline in the markets but we have gotten used to virtually no volatility last week in the last week the Dow dropped one percent two times, two moves of at least one percent. We only had 10 one percent moves in all of 2017. So it's really incredible to low volatility environment that we've all gotten used to.

BARTIROMO: Yes, no wonder trading has been under such pressure for the major banks, right? Coming up this morning, I'll talk exclusively to CEO and President of Wells Fargo, Tim Sloan, my special guest to get reaction to the new Federal Reserve penalties on the bank. Basically putting a limitation as to how big this company can get and how much growth they can actually generate. So timothy Sloan will react to that coming up, that news from the fed announced 6:15 p.m. Eastern on Friday night.

Also joining the conversation this morning Texas Congressman John Ratcliffe one of only three members in Congress to have seen the underlying data and the underlying content of that FISA memo and the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY" Stuart Varney weighing in as well, you don't want to miss a moment of it. We got a big hour coming up and kick it off right here with the top story. President trump headed to Ohio today, he's expected to promote the tax reform overhaul at a plant in Cincinnati while a budget battle rages on a Capitol Hill and senators aim a to end the impasse with a dreamers bill, Blake Burman covering the story at the White House right now with the very latest. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you as well. The president at the White House, the treasury department they say this is the month February when workers will start to see more in their paychecks because of the new tax bill so to that end The President will hit the road today to continue this aggressive sales push. Keep in mind it's still been 47 days since they passed this in the law but he will once again tout this new measure Cincinnati Ohio visit a manufacturer there. The President over the weekend tweeting out wondering why the economy has not gotten more attention saying in the tweet, ''Great jobs numbers and finally after many years rising wages and nobody even talks about that.'' Meantime part of the talk here in Washington is the need to get a spending bill passed by Thursday, it does not appear as if congress has the stomach again forget another shutdown. So one of the questions remains what might happen with an immigration deal? One of the spokespersons over here at the White House Hogan Gidley saying over the weekend that there should be a compromise.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HOGAN GIDLEY, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY PRESS SECRETARY: It is rationale and reasonable, it's 70 percent issue to fix DACA, it's a 70 percent issue for the American people to get border security and chain migration. So there is no reason we should not come to a deal.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Later today Senator John McCain a Republican of course and Chris Coons his Democratic colleague will introduce some new legislation that would include protection for Dreamers also with some measures Maria along the border. This now falls well short of what President Trump has been calling for -- so we will see if this receives some sort of frosty support or really a lack of support from conservatives here in Washington.

BARTIROMO: All right. We are going to watch that, I think they're being - - he is putting the Democrats in a box offering them three times what they actually wanted for the Dreamers Blake. And if they say no to this, you have to question if they actually want a deal.

BURMAN: And that is part of the line now from Republicans all across Washington is they say look it is three times what President Obama had gave or had offered during his administration. So why would you walk away from protecting some 1.8 million people and The President has said he put this out there to see if Democrats really want a deal or not.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. All right. We will keep following that, Blake. Thank you so much. Joining me right now is the Chairman of the House Homeland Security Cybersecurity Committee, Member of the House Judiciary and Ethics Committee, it's Congressman John Ratcliffe of Texas. Congressman, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

REP. JOHN RATCLIFFE, (R) TEXAS: You bet. Hi Maria.

BARTIROMO: I want to get to the FISA memo because I know that you are only one of three members that actually have seen the underlying data but let me just kick off where we just ended with Blake, would you support a bill that offers a path to citizenship for the Dreamers without funding for a border wall.

RATCLIFFE: Well, I think if we get as Republicans, if we get border security, if we get an end to chain-migration, if we end diversity lottery, we've got to give something in return and so some sort of whether it's citizenship or some sort of renewable legal status to some percentage of the Dreamer population, I think Republicans would be on border with that.

BARTIROMO: And so you think that the Republicans will be on border even if it doesn't include actual funding specifically for the wall? Because isn't that what The President said --

RATCLIFFE: No, no.

BARTIROMO: This is -- OK. Yes. I didn't think so .
