urn:contentItem:56MW-9D41-DXH2-6119-00000-003M Company at Citi Global Industrials Conference - Final2012-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis091912a4907554.7543M Companyat CitiGlobal Industrials Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Inge Thulin

3M Company- Chairman, President, CEO

* David Meline

3M Company- SVP, CFO

Presentation

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Get started today and I'd like to welcome you all to the CitiGlobal Industrial Conference. And my apologies if anyone got travel interruptions, trying to make it in last night. I was definitely one of them, but glad that you could all make it and we are delighted to kick off the conference with 3M.

We have both Inge Thulin and David Meline, CEO and CFO, with us. Inge is Chairman, President, and CEO -- he's to my left -- of 3M. He became CEO in February of this year; Chairman in May. And prior to that, Inge was Chief Operating Officer of 3M.

He has held numerous management positions, both domestically and internationally, with 3M since 1979. But he cautions me he joined in grammar school. So, in case anyone is trying to figure out the dates.

And to his left, we have David Moline, CFO. He has held this position since March of last year. He joined 3M in 2008 as Controller and Chief Accounting Officer. Prior to that, he was with General Motors and had roles including CFO of North America and CFO of Europe.

So with that, I'm going to hand the mike over to Inge, who is going to give us a quick update on the Company. Thank you.

INGE THULIN, CHAIRMAN, PRESIDENT, CEO, 3M COMPANY: Okay. Thank you, and good morning. Been in the Company for 30 years, so I'd like to give a little bit of perspective on why this is an incredible Company in terms of competitive advantages. So, first of all, I led the international for eight years became a before I COO last year in May, and then took over the CEO position this year in February.

The competitive advantage and position for 3M is [the capital]. First of all, it's a unique culture of innovation. And innovation, research, and development is the center of the plan for us and has been for many, many years, and will remain with the same as we move forward, which means that we are able to develop new products and solutions for our customers in order for them to become better. So it's an important element in our plan.

We have a broad-based portfolio, and its broad and it's deep. And every segment we are in, on the six business segments, are leading in their respective markets. And all of them have over 20% operating income margins, so very strong position.

Like many strengths from the Company in terms of, first of all, technologies, process manufacturing, global presence, and brand equity and, in addition to that, a very collaborative team around the world that are working together in order to find solutions based on technology platforms. Then, the way we can manufacture that and then how we can commercialize it on a global and local scale, and that's another thing to think about 3M.

We are both global in terms of capabilities, but we're very local in terms of our execution with subsidiaries in most countries around the world, which makes a unique element of us to be first into every country. We don't go through distribution as the first layer into a country. We do it through our own subsidiaries.

There are many leverage points for 3M and one is, of course, manufacturing capabilities. The other one is technologies. And then it's the infrastructure, with subsidiaries around the world that everyone can use as they are moving into the country and commercialize the products. And then we have an embedded operational excellence model that I think we are well known for, well respected for, which is based on Lean Six Sigma.

If you take that together with what we have done over the years, we have had outstanding performance relative to return of investor capital, very strong balance sheet, and we have returned a lot of good cash flow for the shareholders. So if you think about it, since 2004 we have had margins ahead of 20% every year. And we have had a return of invested capital about 20% for the last decade, including 2008 and 2009. So, very impressed impressive from that perspective, and sales have doubled in the last decade from $16 billion to $30 billion.

So -- and relative to this year, then, first half of the year, record sales of $15 billion; records earning per share of $3.25 per share and we took also $0.07 or one-time actions, which was in order to improve our businesses as we move ahead. Pricing was good and productivity was good, specifically relative to manufacturing and productivity. And on top of that, we have been able to really drive a good balance in between investment and cost management during the first part of the year.

As we move ahead, a couple of things that we're doing [which help with] framing us for the future with a new vision for the Company that we've laid out. We have restated six strategies; four are on growth, one around people, and one is around operational excellence. And we have [type of] formed three new divisions into the Company in areas where we believe we have big opportunities for the future.

We formed Mining, Oil, and Gas, as a division. We formed Aerospace as a division, and we formed Defense as a division. So, three new divisions were formed.

We also consolidated six divisions into three divisions. Stationery and Office Supply, two sizable divisions of around $800 million each, was formed and consolidated to one big division, all relative to relevance to the market. Safety, Security, and Track and Trace was consolidated into one business and the same was with the Home Environment that was moved into a Do-It-Yourself Division in the Company. So in terms of forming new divisions for opportunities, three were formed and we were consolidating six into three.

We also made a step-up change relative to our commercialization perspective and appointed a vice president for sales on a global base, vice president of marketing excellence on a global base. And we put the total focus on Lean Six Sigma, also from a central position in order to improve efficiency and productivity, of course, in the Company. So I think those steps are important for us as we move ahead, specifically relatively to what where we stand.

We have a very strong position in research and development; we are very strong in manufacturing; and now we will go for a global execution in terms of commercialization, and that is why we [don't have] stepped up sales and marketing, e-transformation, that type of sense of excellence as we move ahead. So with that, I am done and I think we go to questions and answers to me and David.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Thank you, Inge. As you get seated, one of the reasons we wanted to have 3M kick the conference off is because you touch so many end markets, and especially on a shorter cycle basis, so visibility on the macro is very helpful. And so maybe we can start there.

Geographically, take us through -- let's start with Europe in terms of what you're seeing. It's 23% of your revenues. You're a little bit weaker in the second quarter. Healthcare was fairly strong, but what additional color can you provide at the ground level in Europe today?

INGE THULIN: We just came back from Europe, actually; David and myself and the team was over there last week. And we knew, as we moved into this year, that it would be a tough year. So we had planned very well for that in terms of the efficiency for us and the plan for us in West Europe is very much along operational excellence.

And that had started for us a couple of years back when we [took an] adjusted organization in Europe and went for more regional organizational structure with a subsidiary, [like] subsidiary. So we tried to drive efficiency in the back office, specifically, why we maintained the front and in terms of commercialization. We knew that this would be a tough year and we are operating relative to plan.

We're doing very well in terms of margins. And, I would say, generally speaking, is of course currency that is a headwind for us. But we're very pleased with the way they operate in Europe. And, as I said, this was nothing for us that came as a surprise.

I think had planned for tougher times in Europe, generally speaking, three to four years back when we both separated Central East Europe from West Europe and Middle East/Africa from West Europe. And then in West Europe we regionalized that portion. So we formed or rather had four subsidiaries in Nordic; we now have one regional organization there. The same with Alpine, the same for [Algeria], and the same for Benelux, so it's working well for us.

But it's a tough situation. I think operational excellence is important for us and we take market share.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: You mentioned currency. With the weakening dollar, how does that ripple into, quickly, into the P&L? You're one of the few companies that we cover that those currency hedging. So is it -- what's the delay factor (multiple speakers) see it?

DAVID MELINE, SVP, CFO, 3M COMPANY: So the way we do hedging for the business is, basically, we do it on a 12-month rolling basis and we hedge roughly 50% of our net exposure. So that gives us some visibility. In terms of exchange rate movements, we're able to have some visibility in forecast of the impact of those movements.

So as we finish the second quarter, when we issued guidance, we'd actually indicated that we were updating the outlook for the year assuming the euro would be at EUR1.21 against the dollar. Obviously above EUR1.30 where we are sitting today is certainly supportive to our results on the year. As to how significant that is, quite honestly, it's relatively insignificant within the context of the fact that we only have a few months left in the year.

We have the hedge, which certainly offsets about half of that impact. So I would say no material change vis-a-vis our forecast, but certainly on the margin it's supportive to the results.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: That's helpful. Just go back to Europe for a second. A term we always use and that we look for is destocking. And you, of all your SKUs, can get a flavor whether a destocking element has run through or not. So where does that stand?

INGE THULIN: I think it's very lean. I think most companies today, globally, to be honest, are really -- have taken action relative to the inventory levels. So I think that the stock levels are now very much based on demand, and we don't see any -- have not seen any difference in the last six months.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Okay. China, 9% of revenues; second quarter was exceptionally strong -- 10% organic revenue growth. That's excluding electronics. Again, healthcare was one of the strengths. So from the businesses that you touch today, how does China feel?

INGE THULIN: First of all, the fact that first quarter this year, excluding electronics, was growth of 8%. Second-quarter, as you said, was growth of 10%. China start to slow the second half of last year, as Europe did, meaning that the comparison for the rest of the year will be easier for us. Healthcare is doing very well, not only in China, but broad-based, healthcare for us in international and specifically in developing emerging countries are doing very, very well.

And so when you -- when we look upon -- in China, we know that we will have faster growth in the second part of the year due to comparisons and it seems better. And I think about the three laggards, as we have talked about before relative to China, in terms of consumer electronics, domestic markets and export to West Europe, I think that -- we now hope that both domestic market is coming back, and so consumer electronics export to West Europe will probably take some time.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: If we switch into the US side of the macro, the fiscal cliff, I've heard everything from some off-road equipment customers saying, I'm going to hold off until the elections. Are you seeing that mentality ripple into any 3M's businesses?

INGE THULIN: No, we have -- it's very difficult for us to determine that. I cannot say that we have seen that definition. US, for us, and I would say North America, including Latin America, has been the fastest-growing geographical areas for us in the first part of the year, which is very unusual anyway. And it's very difficult for us to say that there has been any impact relative to the cliff that you are talking about.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: So if we step away from macro -- and certainly, during Q&A, if people have other questions, feel free to focus there. One of the points I wanted to touch on here is, Inge, you took the reins this year for 3M. The idea is I think investors and analysts are still getting to know who you are and what you are tenure as the leader for 3M, how that will develop, and what mark you will make on the Company.

So, from my perspective, you are the consummate insider; so 30 years with the Company, deep culture carrier. So from this point, how do you think investors will see how Inge makes his imprint on the Company?

INGE THULIN: Well, I think, first of all, insider, yes, maybe; but also an outsider. I am very market and customer oriented, and I lived all over the world. So I've had a lot of experience from the outside of 3M relative to the market. So I think that's important to put into the picture.

So I think the other thing that is advantage for me, I've had opportunities to be part of this Company for many years. And for the last 10 years in the two strategic cycles, I was part of the management working on that. And the two cycles had a couple of different characteristics in terms of playbook. The first five years, 2000 to 2005, was very much about efficiency, operational excellence, and productivity through Lean Six Sigma at the time.

The second part was very much about the big dream, really invigorating research and development and drive up the pipeline on new product. And we started to grow slightly better in the second part of the 10-year period. Now when we go into the next five-year period in terms of strategic plan, it's for us to build on those two streams. We have a very strong DNA in the Company relative to operational excellence. As I said in my opening comments, we're now focusing even more on Lean Six Sigma in order to get focused on it, in order for us to maybe to reinvest for growth. So I think, still, that's an opportunity there.

And then it's last to globally commercialize in a more effective way the stronger pipeline we have today versus what we had five, six years ago. And as you know, 3M PDI has gone from maybe [20s] up to [32]. So the pipeline is, by definition, much longer. So now it's becoming a commercialization issue for us while we continue to invest in research and development, which I made a very clear statement that that's the commitment for us as we move ahead.

That's the central to plan. That is the real differentiation for 3M is to be able to invest in research and development and commercialize those products in 3M PDI, in a way, is an important metric. But the very important thing is for us to maintain and improve margins, which we can with the flow of new products that will reposition us and [help our] capital and become even more effective. So that's one thing, so I think you would see a commercialization effort stepped up along that.

I also think that -- I am an individual that believes in privatization. I think privatization will be a clear thing we will talk about relative to make choices as we move ahead, so I think that's also the differences.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: So you tell me -- again, you're probably reading too much into this, but one of the things I've noticed -- and you just said up here this morning -- are some of the organizational changes, the consolidations of divisions, creating new divisions, and also, geographically, setting up the Saudi Arabia, the Sub-Saharan focuses. Is it an organizational imprint also, an organizational focus (multiple speakers)?

INGE THULIN: No. I think it's -- you always talk with the strategists. And the strategies are very much around customers and relevance to customers. I think that's where we start -- what is the relevance for us, relative to customers.

The other thing is where to play and how to win. The third thing is about investment, research and development. If you take those type of things and you think about consolidation of six divisions down to three, that's very much relative to relevance for us in the market with the customers.

And I think it's very easy for many companies that you organize yourself based on internal metrics and not external metrics. So I think that's one thing that, if you say consolidation, which is scale and leverage for us, would be easier to do business with.

The other three divisions that were formed is based on big opportunities in the marketplace, and we need to build that out as a Company and enroll those three places -- Mining, Oil and Gas, Aerospace, and Defense -- we had done business before. But the way we did it was by not focusing in with full investment into research and development. So we took basically what we had in the pipeline, went to market, and tried to commercialize that.

It's my view, what you need to have in order to win, you need to have your own capabilities in terms of research and development so you can get an organic draw through your own pipeline and new products. And in addition to that, when you put the strong management team in place, which we did, they will also be able to create a much stronger business case for eventually other investments, which could include mergers and acquisitions such as we have. But that's where you try to go with it. So I think strategy is first, structure second.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: And it's probably not a coincidence that when you set up those two divisions right out of the box first quarter, they killed it with, I guess, Natural Resources were up 20% and Arrow up 24%. So if you're going to set them up, you want to set them up with some momentum?

INGE THULIN: Yes, that's right. I don't think we saw the results already first quarter, to be honest, based on the organization change. The point was, they were doing very well and now the point is how can we accelerate as to that. When we saw all those EBOs, as we call the emerging business opportunities that were put in place, as I said, we tried to commercialize what was already in the pipeline. When we know it's working, then we put more efforts into it.

So I think we should see even more acceleration. And we have big expectations of those businesses as we now have formed them, right. That's why we expect them to go even faster.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: So the invitation just went out yesterday for the November 8 analyst day in Minneapolis. Matt Ginter will probably cringe if I start out too much to steal any of the thunder he has planned. But one of the questions I have to ask is the 3M pyramid, is that going to be something that will be -- continue to be worshipped and focused and explained, or will that be something that gets put into the closet?

INGE THULIN: The pyramid is a way of describing the marketplace and what we are doing in the strategy is to expand our relevance in the market. So I think that the pyramid is more a symbolic way of talking about the total market in terms of our expansion. So we are continuing to work a way to improve our relevance to the customers, to expand the marketplace in terms of presence, both from a portfolio perspective, but also geographically.

So, conceptually, it's something that is there. And I think it's [easier] for us to manage it with our competitive platforms in order to make sure wherever we compete in the marketplace, that we make money. And for us, in many cases, it's the market share gain, specifically in developed economies, but is profitable market share. We are not after market share for the purpose of market share. You need to be profitable as we take them.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: One of the -- in addition to inheriting an earnings guidance for the year, which has been reaffirmed in the second quarter, you also have inherited and you are part of this plan to put -- that set a 7% to 8% organic revenue growth over the course of the cycle. We touched on it previous earnings call; it's still investors' top of mind.

Is that still achievable? Has the market changed? Has the mix changed at all in terms of what the potential is for that type of growth?

INGE THULIN: Yes, I think the market has changed since that target was put in place. So it was done in a different economical environment and it was based on what the consensus externally was, relative to the GDP and IPI growth on a global base. So, 7% to 8% were put in place in that environment.

Now it's a stretch target in a way that, in 3M, we had an organization that responds very well to stretches. So, still, I would say 7% to 8% is a type of stretch target, but I think in an economical environment has changed relative to how achievable that is. So I think that's the answer to the question.

But -- and I think that if you look up on the last 10 years for us, our growth rate has been actually 7% to 8% in total. Half of that was organic, and we grew 1.5x IPI during that period of time. So we've been, in the last period, grown 3% to 4% organically and now we need to step that up a little bit. So I would say it's a stretch target.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Just in terms of protocol, just as a reminder, so you are going to have a November 8 meeting in Minneapolis. The typical December meeting you have in New York will be a conference call.

DAVID MELINE: That's correct, yes. That's correct.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: And anything else you can share about the agenda, maybe to start whipping up expectations and a frenzy to get people to storm up to Minneapolis?

DAVID MELINE: Yes, well, it's always beautiful in Minneapolis in December, as all of us know, so we certainly welcome -- I'm sorry, in November. But, yes, so in November we'll be doing a full review of the businesses. So we'll have several of the sector leaders presenting there.

Inge will obviously have a significant portion of the morning, where we'll have a chance to discuss in much more depth the vision and strategies for the Company, how we're going to deploy against those. And then will also have -- I'll do an update as to our longer-term thinking around financial objectives and metrics. So I think it will be a really interesting morning and we hope all of you are able to make it out there.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: I can see Matt Ginter kind of saying, don't disclose too much. All right.

So, one of the news items I think caught some people by surprise when it was announced, we thought there would be some issues from a regulatory standpoint is the Avery Dennison office products. So just kind of -- and there was some back-and-forth in terms of press announcements. Just kind of frame for us what happened and where it goes from here.

DAVID MELINE: Yes. So, first of all, there's no new developments in the last -- since the news came out a couple of weeks ago. For those of you who may not be familiar, we entered into a purchase agreement late last year for Avery Dennison's Office Products Group -- $550 million acquisition of that business, to complement our existing office and stationery products business.

We've been going through regulatory review over the last month, and two weeks ago the Justice Department informed us that they were going to block the transaction. And at that time, we then jointly withdrew our Hart Scott Rodino filing. And what we felt the best course of action for the Company at that time was to look at the concerns the DoJ had an attempt to address those. So that's what we're doing right now. So, stay tuned.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: There's still a potential that something could --

DAVID MELINE: They have a contract that remains in place at the present time and we are reviewing the situation.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Okay. And are there -- just give us a quick update on M&A pipeline, expectations for this year with the budget, and maybe pricing and so forth.

INGE THULIN: Maybe I can make some comments on that. First of all, our commitment relative to the value of being $1 billion to $2 billion and we stand behind that. So it will be in terms of value that's important, as we have seen in the last strategic planning session.

You will probably see slightly bigger than we have done in the past, meaning maybe fewer or slightly bigger. So we did a lot during the last 5 to 6 years, I think with it's around [70]. And so I think you will see fewer, but the most strategically important for us and linked into some of the growth opportunities we see. And they should be a little bit more sizable for us, and they should also -- we should also be able to leverage them and broad-based as we do them, meaning from a technology perspective or from a geographical perspective.

So that's an important element, but again, our prime strategy is of course organic growth. So the strategy in terms of acquisition is tactically in order to supplement our position as we move ahead. But we are committed to it. The pipeline looked good.

We are looking at broad-based because it's also a way for us to get the good feeling of the total market and how it looks like. So everyone is working on it. We will, David and myself, together with the team, we will prioritize, however, based on strategic importance as we move ahead.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Anything you can comment on in terms of pricing, seller expectations?

DAVID MELINE: Yes, I would say, I mean, if you look at the pipeline today -- and, first of all, just to remind us that -- and as we've seen with this recent transaction, we set out a plan of $1 billion to $2 billion deploying against acquisitions this year. The timing is always uncertain as to when you close. So as to whether we will end up in that place this year is still not clear.

In terms of the pipeline, it's good. I would say we feel good about the pipeline. We feel good about the situation we are in, in that. I would say there is more realistic expectations right now in terms of sellers' expectations than perhaps it was a year and a half ago. And given where we are, given the strength of our balance sheet, that puts us obviously in a very good position to be able to transact, should we identify opportunities that are interesting to us.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: I want to make sure I had time for any audience questions. So, people, there is a mike around. I know it's still early so there may not be -- and I'm being blocked by a podium here too. So as you mull over questions, how about -- hopefully, you understand this is a high quality problem.

Second quarter I think more than half the analysts on the conference call asked about pricing. And it was the fact that it was so strong, so it evokes how sustainable is that. But nearly 2%, you raised the higher end for the year. Just in terms of where it goes from here, the sustainability, and what that tells you both about new products and the visibility into 2013.

INGE THULIN: Well, maybe I can talk on that. First of all, we took action early in order to make sure, and I think that's the strength of 3M and order to be able to balance what we can do based in terms of demand and raw material increases. So we took action early in order both to make sure that we compensate for raw material increases, at the same time a sure that we still could play in the market based on demand. And it came in place.

We have -- so our outcome was very, very strong year today, and it's sticking as we move ahead. So I think it's, again, an advantage for us because we often are the price leader in the market segment. So that's also why we, in many cases, can go early when we see raw material coming in and play a potentially negative (inaudible).

DAVID MELINE: Yes, I would just add to that. So if you look at how price and raw materials trends have developed over really the last now year and a half, we saw very strong raw material cost increases last year exceeding 4%, which is as high as we've seen as a Company in recent history. We had 1% recovery in price last year, which is basically neutralizing that raw material cost impact, in that about 25% of any dollar of revenue is in the form of raw materials.

As we came into the year, then, we continued to look at the opportunities to get some price performance. We saw momentum in that a lot of the price that was put in place last year only impacted us in the second half. So that momentum carried into the first half.

So what happens now, as we move forward, the comp gets more difficult because we had price in the second half of last year. And I would say offsetting that is, not surprisingly, raw material costs have certainly softened to the point where we see raw material cost impacts in the second half being either flat or perhaps slightly negative. So that will be a contributor to our profitability and margins here through the balance of the year. I would say not as strong as the first half, but certainly we'll see that continue.

Questions and Answers

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Question up front, yes. We have a mike coming around, too.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Hi. The mining end market has been slightly controversy over recently. Can you please address the trends that you are seeing there?

INGE THULIN: Controversial in terms of --?

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Whether there have been some changes in CapEx budgets in Latin America and (multiple speakers) Australia.

INGE THULIN: Yes, there has. I think you have to look upon it relative to our relative position and the way we bill it out. For us today, that is around a $900 million business, which we try to ramp up in the plan up to $2 billion. So our base, after this point in time, has been very much around safety and security products.

And when we try to do now is move into new spaces. So I think even if that is happening, which I think it's a cyclical thing, that will not have any indication for us relative to how we view that opportunity long-term as a Company.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Other questions? Here we go.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: Can you make a comment on the percentage of sales that you spend on R&D? Are you satisfied with the amount of R&D that you're spending at the moment?

INGE THULIN: Yes. First of all, we have spent over the years around 5%, 5.5%, 6%. I think at times it was up to 7% when we had pharma as part of the portfolio. As we speak, one of the strategies we are laying out, and it's the third strategy of six, is actually starting with a statement saying invest in innovation. So that's a statement for us in order to make sure that we focus on it and that we upscale the investment as we move ahead.

I think the outcome as we're spending today around 5.5% is not bad in terms of the new product vitality index. I think that we will like to see is what we call Class V, new products to the world, right, which is something that we would like to move resources in order to invest more in. So I think that's the big opportunity for us.

It is, AS I said, it's central to the plan for 3M and I think we have been effective in terms of our investment up to this point in time. But we are very -- and David and myself are the whole time challenged, saying that line, if you like, to make sure that we as an organization, the whole time, make sure that we invest on the right level in order to be able to commercialize those products, because we believe that is the big differentiator for 3M. So I think it should be somewhere in between 5% to 6% is the right level for us as we go forward as well.

UNIDENTIFIED AUDIENCE MEMBER: This is a follow-up to that R&D question is -- how do you optimize R&D spend? There is that Lean and Six Sigma approach, but you can't just walk into the lab and say, innovate, and then expect to see the stream of new products. George used to talk about, say, look, I don't take wheelbarrows of cash and dump it into the R&D section. And so how do you optimize?

INGE THULIN: Well, first of all, when you look upon research and development, I think we have to separate them in between research and then development. And the research part is 15% and the development part is 85%.

And I would say the development part is more into the divisions and subsidiaries in terms of working on products that can be commercialized on a shorter term cycle. The research is where people work [with a 45] technology platforms is coming up with really new to the world technologies that we have done so successfully over many years.

I think on the 15% part, the technique there is to not ask question of commercialization times. When will it be commercialized? Those individuals need to have the freedom to work on big projects that will take time and that will be a big benefit to the Company long-term, when they are ready to go to what I would say the development phase.

In the development phase, into the division of subsidiaries, that is where you have to make sure that is clear guidelines and clear milestones. And that is where we ask the question relative to commercialization, so you are not losing the view of that you have to go to market, right, because it's not only a research and development. It's also to be able to commercialize them and do that successfully in time.

So I think that's much more focused into the division. And that's happening, I would say, in what we call a product steering committee in each division. And they are meeting monthly and they have timelines in terms of -- [engage] where they review the projects in order to continue or to stop the project. So that's working pretty well.

But I think your point earlier is to say that, in many cases, you cannot push too much dashboards specifically when you are going to look upon the research part, right, which is where people work on -- with four to five technology platforms to combine them and come with new to the world technologies that could revolutionize some of the businesses. And we have many examples of that in the past, like micro applications and other things like that. It took a long time before it happened. Now a big portion of the Company is utilizing that technology in very successfully commercialized products.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: And do researchers still have an ability to spend a portion of their time on assigned projects, things that they want to -- have a special interest in? What is that arrangement? Because it's been historically pointed to as one of the hallmarks of the 3M lab.

INGE THULIN: Yes. The 15% rule is still there. And David and myself, actually yesterday, was that we had a big tech forum yesterday where they shared all projects going on in the Company. It was a fantastic event that we went to.

And one big section of that event was the [up to] 15% projects where people showed what they are doing based on the 15% time that they are putting in. Today that'd still alive. We're talking about it.

It was a big portion of the -- not the biggest, but the big portion of the section yesterday. And we have commented yesterday as we flew in that it was actually a really fun afternoon for us, because that's where we saw the future of the Company relative to products. So the 15% is still alive.

UNIDENTIFIED SPEAKER: Well, I'm going to suggest that that be part of the November 8 analyst meeting. We should bring just the highlights of those if we could. So with that, I want to thank 3M, Inge, David, for presenting here this morning.

INGE THULIN: Okay. Thank you.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKM-KN21-F03R-N2CK-00000-003 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech'2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech'ilene

Jul 17, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) 3 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech' Before taking on tech giants, shatter a few misconceptions. W. Scott McGill/Shutterstock.com[1] Courtesy ofBhaskar Chakravorti[2], Tufts University[3] As the public and government regulators around the world discuss whether and how[4] to manage the power of technology companies, one idea that keeps coming up is breaking up these large conglomerate corporations into smaller pieces. Public distrust for tech companies has shifted to talk of antitrust action[5] against them. Facebook, for instance, might then have to compete with Instagram for photo-sharing[6] and WhatsApp for messaging - rather than owning both. The idea has managed to garner support from both Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren[7], a Democrat, and Republican President Donald Trump[8]. However, advocates[9] and opponents[10] of breaking up big technology firms are falling prey to some serious misconceptions. I study the effects of digital technologies on lives and livelihoods across 85 countries and lead Tufts Fletcher School's Digital Planet[11] initiative studying technological innovation around the world. In my opinion, there are three myths worth busting before considering taking on big tech. Myth 1: Comparing Standard Oil and Google   https://images.theconversation.com/files/284102/original/file-20190715-173370-5ovggf.png?ixlib=rb-1.1.0...5...o=format...000...=clip John D. Rockefeller, founder of Standard Oil.

Urbanrenewal/Wikimedia Commons[12] Arguments for and against antitrust action against tech firms rely heavily on the experiences of earlier cases[13]. The massive 19th-century monopoly Standard Oil[14] has, in fact, been referred to as the 'Google of its day[15].' There are also people who are recalling the 1990s antitrust case against Microsoft's dominant position[16] in the era of personal computers. https://images.theconversation.com/files/284103/original/file-20190715-173360-2qxmqd.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0...5...o=format...000...=clipGoogle co-founders Sergey Brin, left, and Larry Page. Joi Ito/Wikimedia Commons[17], CC BY[18] Those cases from the past may seem similar to today's situation, but this era is different in one crucial way: the global technology marketplace. Currently, there are two parallel 'big tech' clusters. One is in the U.S., dominated by Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple[19]. The other is based in China, dominated by Baidu, Alibaba, Tencent and Huawei[20]. This global market is subject to different political and policy pressures than regulators faced when dealing with Standard Oil and Microsoft. Both clusters are attempting to add users to accumulate reservoirs of data[21], which will fuel the next stage of competitiveness in a future run by artificial intelligence. The Chinese government has blocked most of the U.S. companies from entering the Chinese market, protecting its 'AI national team[22].' The U.S. government has done likewise[23], blacklisting some Chinese outfits for a period while discouraging others. If the U.S. technology giants are broken up, the result would be a vastly uneven global playing field, pitting fragmented U.S. companies against consolidated state-protected Chinese firms. Geopolitical factors aren't limited to the U.S.-China rivalry. The European Union, Russia and India are also heavy users of Silicon Valley technologies, and each is exploring its own options[24] for legislation and regulation too. U.S. companies' size and data accumulation capabilities give the country economic and political influence around the globe. Their power would change if they were broken up - and, in my view, that should be a key consideration in regulators' decisions. Myth 2: Price is right There are two main views of antitrust action in these discussions. One focuses on consumer welfare, which has been the prevailing approach federal lawyers have taken since the 1960s[25]. The other view suggests that regulators should look at the underlying structure of the market[26] and potential for powerful players to exploit[27] their positions. Those two sides seem to agree that price plays a key role. People who argue against breaking up the tech giants point out that Facebook and Google provide services that are free to the consumer[28], and that Amazon's marketplace power drives its products' costs down. On the other side, though, are those who say that having low or no prices[29] is evidence that these companies are artificially lowering consumer costs to draw users into company-controlled systems that are hard to leave[30]. Both sides are missing the fact that the monetary price is less relevant as measure of what users pay in the technology industry than it is in other types of business. Users pay for digital products with their data[31], rather than just money. Regulators shouldn't focus only on the monetary costs to the users. Rather, they should ask whether users are being asked for more data than is strictly necessary, whether information is being collected in intrusive or abusive ways[32] and whether customers are getting good value in exchange for their data[33]. Myth 3: Trust-busting is all or nothing There aren't just two ways for this debate to end, with either a breakup of one or more technology giants or simply leaving things as they are for the market to develop further. My own idea of the best outcome would take a page from the history of antitrust litigation: The company that is sued is not broken up, and yet the very fact that there was a lawsuit leads to progress. That has happened in the past, in the cases against the Bell System, IBM and Microsoft.   https://images.theconversation.com/files/284111/original/file-20190715-173376-1k7ro27.jpg?ixlib=rb-1.1.0...5...o=format...000...=clip A replica of the first transistor, developed at AT... Bell Laboratories in 1947. National Archives[34] In the 1956 federal consent decree against the Bell System, which settled a seven-year legal proceeding against the company, the company wasn't split up, but Bell was required to license all its patents royalty-free[35] to other firms. This meant that some of the most profound technological innovations in history - including the transistor[36], the solar cell[37] and the laser[38] - became widely available, yielding computers, solar power and other technologies that are crucial to the modern world. When the Bell System was eventually broken up[39] in 1982, it did not do nearly as much to spread innovation and competition[40] as the agreement that kept the Bells together a quarter-century earlier. The antitrust action against IBM lasted 13 years and didn't break up the firm. However, as part of its tactics to avoid appearing to be a monopoly, IBM agreed to separate pricing for its hardware and software products[41], previously sold as an indivisible bundle. This created an opportunity for entrepreneurs Bill Gates and Paul Allen to create a new software-only company, called Microsoft. The surge of software innovations that have followed can clearly trace their origins to the IBM settlement. Two decades later, Microsoft was itself the target of an antitrust action. In the resulting settlement, Microsoft agreed to ensure its products were compatible[42] with competitors' software. That made room in the emerging internet marketplace for web browsers, the predecessors of Apple's Safari, Mozilla's Firefox and Google Chrome. Even Margrethe Vestager, the European Union's top antitrust official and frequent tech-giant nemesis, has said that 'Antitrust prosecutions are part of how technology grows[43].' But that doesn't mean they all have to achieve their most extreme ends, of breaking up the companies. Antitrust rules are complicated enough, and plenty of experts will be called on to give their views on what to do with 'big tech.' Technology pervades every aspect of modern lives, giving each person a responsibility to weigh in on this issue without misconceptions clouding their judgments. Technology has become a political issue. In a politically overheated climate, public sentiments may matter even more than the opinions of experts. Bhaskar Chakravorti[44], Dean of Global Business, The Fletcher School, Tufts University[45] This article is republished from The Conversation[46] under a Creative Commons license. urn:contentItem:5WKH-SC01-F05M-K1P0-00000-003 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech'2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech'Bhaskar Chakravorti

As the public and government regulators around the world discuss whether and how to manage the power of technology companies, one idea that keeps coming up is breaking up these large conglomerate corporations into smaller pieces. Public distrust for tech companies has shifted to talk of    antitrust action against them. Facebook, for instance, might then have to    compete with Instagram for photo-sharing and WhatsApp for messaging - rather than owning both.

The idea has managed to garner support from both Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat, and    Republican President Donald Trump.

However, advocates and    opponents of breaking up big technology firms are falling prey to some serious misconceptions. I study the effects of digital technologies on lives and livelihoods across 85 countries and lead Tufts Fletcher School's    Digital Planet initiative studying technological innovation around the world. In my opinion, there are three myths worth busting before considering taking on big tech.

Arguments for and against antitrust action against tech firms rely heavily on the experiences of earlier cases. The massive    19th-century monopoly Standard Oil has, in fact, been referred to as the "   Google of its day." There are also people who are recalling the 1990s    antitrust case against Microsoft's dominant position in the era of personal computers.

Those cases from the past may seem similar to today's situation, but this era is different in one crucial way: the global technology marketplace. Currently, there are two parallel "big tech" clusters. One is in the U.S., dominated by Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple. The other is based in China, dominated by    Baidu, Alibaba, Tencent and Huawei. This global market is subject to different political and policy pressures than regulators faced when dealing with Standard Oil and Microsoft.

Both clusters are attempting to add users to accumulate reservoirs of data, which will fuel the next stage of competitiveness in a future run by artificial intelligence. The Chinese government has blocked most of the U.S. companies from entering the Chinese market, protecting its "   AI national team." The    U.S. government has done likewise, blacklisting some Chinese outfits for a period while discouraging others.

If the U.S. technology giants are broken up, the result would be a vastly uneven global playing field, pitting fragmented U.S. companies against consolidated state-protected Chinese firms.

Geopolitical factors aren't limited to the U.S.-China rivalry. The European Union, Russia and India are also heavy users of Silicon Valley technologies, and each is exploring its own options for legislation and regulation too.

U.S. companies' size and data accumulation capabilities give the country economic and political influence around the globe. Their power would change if they were broken up - and, in my view, that should be a key consideration in regulators' decisions.

There are two main views of antitrust action in these discussions. One focuses on consumer welfare, which has been the prevailing approach federal lawyers have taken since the 1960s. The other view suggests that regulators should look at the    underlying structure of the market and potential for    powerful players to exploit their positions.

Those two sides seem to agree that price plays a key role. People who argue against breaking up the tech giants point out that Facebook and Google provide services that are free to the consumer, and that Amazon's marketplace power drives its products' costs down. On the other side, though, are those who say that    having low or no prices is evidence that these companies are artificially lowering consumer costs to draw users into company-controlled systems that are    hard to leave.

Both sides are missing the fact that the monetary price is less relevant as measure of what users pay in the technology industry than it is in other types of business. Users pay for digital products with their data, rather than just money. Regulators shouldn't focus only on the monetary costs to the users. Rather, they should ask whether users are being asked for more data than is strictly necessary, whether information is being collected in    intrusive or abusive ways and whether customers are    getting good value in exchange for their data.

There aren't just two ways for this debate to end, with either a breakup of one or more technology giants or simply leaving things as they are for the market to develop further.

My own idea of the best outcome would take a page from the history of antitrust litigation: The company that is sued is not broken up, and yet the very fact that there was a lawsuit leads to progress. That has happened in the past, in the cases against the Bell System, IBM and Microsoft.

In the 1956 federal consent decree against the Bell System, which settled a seven-year legal proceeding against the company, the company wasn't split up, but Bell was required to license all its patents royalty-free to other firms. This meant that some of the most profound technological innovations in history - including the    transistor, the    solar cell and the    laser - became widely available, yielding computers, solar power and other technologies that are crucial to the modern world. When the Bell System was    eventually broken up in 1982, it did not do nearly as much to spread    innovation and competition as the agreement that kept the Bells together a quarter-century earlier.

The antitrust action against IBM lasted 13 years and didn't break up the firm. However, as part of its tactics to avoid appearing to be a monopoly, IBM agreed to separate pricing for its hardware and software products, previously sold as an indivisible bundle. This created an opportunity for entrepreneurs Bill Gates and Paul Allen to create a new software-only company, called Microsoft. The surge of software innovations that have followed can clearly trace their origins to the IBM settlement.

Two decades later, Microsoft was itself the target of an antitrust action. In the resulting settlement, Microsoft agreed to ensure its products were compatible with competitors' software. That made room in the emerging internet marketplace for web browsers, the predecessors of Apple's Safari, Mozilla's Firefox and Google Chrome.

Even Margrethe Vestager, the European Union's top antitrust official and frequent tech-giant nemesis, has said that "Antitrust prosecutions are part of how technology grows." But that doesn't mean they all have to achieve their most extreme ends, of breaking up the companies.

Antitrust rules are complicated enough, and plenty of experts will be called on to give their views on what to do with "big tech." Technology pervades every aspect of modern lives, giving each person a responsibility to weigh in on this issue without misconceptions clouding their judgments. Technology has become a political issue. In a politically overheated climate, public sentiments may matter even more than the opinions of experts.

Bhaskar Chakravorti is the dean of global business at The Fletcher School within Tufts University. This article is republished from The Conversation under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article.

The idea has managed to garner support from both Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat, and Republican US President Donald J. Trump.

I study the effects of digital technologies on lives and livelihoods across 85 countries and lead Tufts Fletcher School's Digital Planet initiative studying technological innovation around the world. Bhaskar Chakravorti has founded and directs the Institute for Business in the Global Context at Fletcher/Tufts that has received funding from Mastercard, Microsoft, the Gates Foundation, the Rockefeller Foundation and the Onassis Foundation. He is a Non-Resident Senior Fellow at Brookings India and a Senior Advisor on Digital Inclusion at the Mastercard Center for Inclusive Growth.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WKH-2NV1-JCNX-34Y5-00000-003 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech'2019-07-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 myths to bust about breaking up 'big tech'

Link to Image

Link to Story

As the public and government regulators around the world discusswhether and howto manage the power of technology companies, one idea that keeps coming up is breaking up these large conglomerate corporations into smaller pieces. Public distrust for tech companies has shifted to talk ofantitrust actionagainst them. Facebook, for instance, might then have tocompete with Instagram for photo-sharingand WhatsApp for messaging - rather than owning both. The idea has managed to garner support from bothMassachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren , a Democrat, andRepublican President Donald Trump .However,advocatesandopponentsof breaking up big technology firms are falling prey to some serious misconceptions. I study the effects of digital technologies on lives and livelihoods across 85 countries and lead Tufts Fletcher School'sDigital Planetinitiative studying technological innovation around the world. In my opinion, there are three myths worth busting before considering taking on big tech.


Myth 1: Comparing Standard Oil and Google


John D. Rockefeller, founder of Standard Oil.
Urbanrenewal/Wikimedia Commons
Arguments for and against antitrust action against tech firms rely heavily on theexperiences of earlier cases . The massive19th-century monopoly Standard Oilhas, in fact, been referred to as the ' Google of its day .' There are also people who are recalling the 1990santitrust case against Microsoft's dominant positionin the era of personal computers.


Google co-founders Sergey Brin, left, and Larry Page.
Joi Ito/Wikimedia Commons ,CC BY
Those cases from the past may seem similar to today's situation, but this era is different in one crucial way: the global technology marketplace. Currently, there are two parallel 'big tech' clusters. One is in the U.S., dominated byGoogle, Amazon, Facebook and Apple . The other is based in China, dominated byBaidu, Alibaba, Tencent and Huawei . This global market is subject to different political and policy pressures than regulators faced when dealing with Standard Oil and Microsoft.Both clusters are attempting to add users toaccumulate reservoirs of data , which will fuel the next stage of competitiveness in a future run by artificial intelligence. The Chinese government has blocked most of the U.S. companies from entering the Chinese market, protecting its ' AI national team .' TheU.S. government has done likewise , blacklisting some Chinese outfits for a period while discouraging others.If the U.S. technology giants are broken up, the result would be a vastly uneven global playing field, pitting fragmented U.S. companies against consolidated state-protected Chinese firms.Geopolitical factors aren't limited to the U.S.-China rivalry. The European Union, Russia and India are also heavy users of Silicon Valley technologies, and each isexploring its own optionsfor legislation and regulation too.U.S. companies' size and data accumulation capabilities give the country economic and political influence around the globe. Their power would change if they were broken up - and, in my view, that should be a key consideration in regulators' decisions.
Myth 2: Price is rightThere are two main views of antitrust action in these discussions. One focuses on consumer welfare, which has been the prevailing approach federal lawyers have takensince the 1960s . The other view suggests that regulators should look at theunderlying structure of the marketand potential forpowerful players to exploittheir positions.Those two sides seem to agree that price plays a key role. People who argue against breaking up the tech giants point out that Facebook and Google provide services that arefree to the consumer , and that Amazon's marketplace power drives its products' costs down. On the other side, though, are those who say thathaving low or no pricesis evidence that these companies are artificially lowering consumer costs to draw users into company-controlled systems that arehard to leave .Both sides are missing the fact that the monetary price is less relevant as measure of what users pay in the technology industry than it is in other types of business. Userspay for digital products with their data , rather than just money. Regulators shouldn't focus only on the monetary costs to the users. Rather, they should ask whether users are being asked for more data than is strictly necessary, whether information is being collected inintrusive or abusive waysand whether customers aregetting good value in exchange for their data .
Myth 3: Trust-busting is all or nothingThere aren't just two ways for this debate to end, with either a breakup of one or more technology giants or simply leaving things as they are for the market to develop further. My own idea of the best outcome would take a page from the history of antitrust litigation: The company that is sued is not broken up, and yet the very fact that there was a lawsuit leads to progress. That has happened in the past, in the cases against the Bell System, IBM and Microsoft.


A replica of the first transistor, developed at AT & T's Bell Laboratories in 1947.
National Archives
In the 1956 federal consent decree against the Bell System, which settled a seven-year legal proceeding against the company, the company wasn't split up, but Bell was required tolicense all its patents royalty-freeto other firms. This meant that some of the most profound technological innovations in history - including thetransistor , thesolar celland thelaser- became widely available, yielding computers, solar power and other technologies that are crucial to the modern world. When the Bell System waseventually broken upin 1982, it did not do nearly as much to spreadinnovation and competitionas the agreement that kept the Bells together a quarter-century earlier. The antitrust action against IBM lasted 13 years and didn't break up the firm. However, as part of its tactics to avoid appearing to be a monopoly, IBM agreed toseparate pricing for its hardware and software products , previously sold as an indivisible bundle. This created an opportunity for entrepreneurs Bill Gates and Paul Allen to create a new software-only company, called Microsoft. The surge of software innovations that have followed can clearly trace their origins to the IBM settlement. Two decades later, Microsoft was itself the target of an antitrust action. In the resulting settlement,Microsoft agreed to ensure its products were compatiblewith competitors' software. That made room in the emerging internet marketplace for web browsers, the predecessors of Apple's Safari, Mozilla's Firefox and Google Chrome.Even Margrethe Vestager, the European Union's top antitrust official and frequent tech-giant nemesis, has said that ' Antitrust prosecutions are part of how technology grows .' But that doesn't mean they all have to achieve their most extreme ends, of breaking up the companies. Antitrust rules are complicated enough, and plenty of experts will be called on to give their views on what to do with 'big tech.' Technology pervades every aspect of modern lives, giving each person a responsibility to weigh in on this issue without misconceptions clouding their judgments. Technology has become a political issue. In a politically overheated climate, public sentiments may matter even more than the opinions of experts.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WM9-V6S1-F08V-617D-00000-003 myths to bust about breaking up ‘big tech’2019-07-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexisBPg. 0033 myths to bust about breaking up ‘big tech’ Bhaskar Chakravorti The Conversation

As the public and government regulators around the world discuss whether and how to manage the power of technology companies, one idea that keeps coming up is breaking up these large conglomerate corporations into smaller pieces. Public distrust for tech companies has shifted to talk of antitrust action against them. Facebook, for instance, might then have to compete with Instagram for photo-sharing and WhatsApp for messaging, rather than owning both.

The idea has managed to garner support from Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat, and Republican President Donald Trump. However, advocates and opponents of breaking up big technology firms are falling prey to serious misconceptions. I study the effects of digital technologies on lives and livelihoods across 85 countries. There are three myths worth busting before considering taking on big tech.

Myth 1: Comparing Standard Oil and Google. Arguments for and against antitrust action against tech firms rely heavily on earlier cases. The massive 19th-century monopoly Standard Oil has, in fact, been referred to as the “Google of its day.” There are also people who cite the 1990s antitrust case against Microsoft’s dominant position in the era of personal computers.

Those cases from the past might seem similar to today’s situation, but this era is different in one crucial way: the global technology marketplace. There are two parallel “big tech” clusters. One is in the U.S., dominated by Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple. The other is based in China, dominated by Baidu, Alibaba, Tencent and Huawei. This global market is subject to different political and policy pressures than regulators faced when dealing with Standard Oil and Microsoft.

Both clusters are attempting to add users to accumulate reservoirs of data, which will fuel the next stage of competitiveness in a future run by artificial intelligence. The Chinese government has blocked most of the U.S. companies from entering the Chinese market, protecting its “AI national team.” The U.S. government has done likewise, blacklisting some Chinese outfits for a period while discouraging others.

If U.S. technology giants are broken up, the result would be a vastly uneven global playing field, pitting fragmented U.S. companies against consolidated, state-protected Chinese firms. Geopolitical factors aren’t limited to the U.S.-China rivalry. The European Union, Russia and India are also heavy users of Silicon Valley technologies, and each is exploring its own options for legislation and regulation too.

Myth 2: Price is right. There are two main views of antitrust action in these discussions. One focuses on consumer welfare, which has been the prevailing approach federal lawyers have taken since the 1960s. The other view suggests that regulators should look at the underlying structure of the market and potential for powerful players to exploit their positions.

Those two sides seem to agree that price plays a key role. People who argue against breaking up the tech giants point out that Facebook and Google provide services that are free to the consumer, and that Amazon’s marketplace power drives its products’ costs down. On the other side are those who say that having low or no prices is evidence that these companies are artificially lowering consumer costs to draw users into company-controlled systems that are hard to leave.

Both sides are missing the fact that the monetary price is less relevant as a measure of what users pay in the technology industry than it is in other types of business. Users pay for digital products with their data, rather than just money. Regulators shouldn’t focus only on the monetary costs to the users. They should ask whether users are being asked for more data than strictly necessary, whether information is being collected in intrusive or abusive ways and whether customers are getting good value in exchange for their data.

Myth 3: Trust-busting is all or nothing. There aren’t just two ways for this debate to end, with either a breakup of one or more technology giants or simply leaving things as they are for the market to develop further.

The best outcome would take a page from the history of antitrust litigation: The company that is sued is not broken up, and yet the fact there was a lawsuit leads to progress. That has happened in the past, in the cases against the Bell System, IBM and Microsoft.

In the 1956 federal consent decree against the Bell System, which settled a seven-year legal proceeding against the company, the company wasn’t split up, but Bell was required to license all its patents royalty-free to other firms. This meant that some of the most profound technological innovations in history, including the transistor, the solar cell and the laser, became widely available, yielding computers, solar power and other technologies that are crucial to the modern world. When the Bell System was eventually broken up in 1982, it did not do nearly as much to spread innovation and competition as the agreement that kept the Bells together a quarter-century earlier.

Even Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s top antitrust official and frequent tech-giant nemesis, has said that “Antitrust prosecutions are part of how technology grows.” But that doesn’t mean they all have to break up the companies.

Antitrust rules are complicated enough, and plenty of experts will be called on to give their views on what to do with “big tech.” Technology pervades every aspect of modern lives, giving each person a responsibility to weigh in on this issue without misconceptions clouding their judgments. Technology has become a political issue. In a politically overheated climate, public sentiments may matter more than the opinions of experts.

Bhaskar Chakravorti is the dean of global business at Tufts University’s Fletcher School.

David Marcus, CEO of Facebook’s Calibra digital wallet service, speaks during a House Financial Services Committee hearing on Facebook’s proposed cryptocurrency on Capitol Hill on Wednesday. Andrew Harnik, Associated Press

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WB1-3RC1-JDJN-6160-00000-003 objectives to advance with AI2019-06-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 objectives to advance with AI

Artificial intelligence is what will take technology to the next level. However, simply incorporating a bunch of AI applications is not the answer. There are three challenges that need to be overcome in order to fully harness the potential of AI:

Demystifying AI: Most people do not really know what AI is and how it functions. Perhaps that's the reason 40% of European AI startups had nothing to do with AI, but got investor's attention simply because they called themselves so. So dig deeper into AI, learn to code, and understand the whys and hows of AI coding.


Both powerful incumbents trying to evade disruption and SMEs aiming for growth will have to learn to drive AI, or else yield to the juggernaut of Big Tech currently monopolising the space. Jason Davis, INSEAD Associate Professor of Entrepreneurship and Family Enterprise

Know the ins and outs of AI coding to understand the possibilities that could become realities. You'll be able to determine the applications of AI to truly create value for companies instead of just incorporating the latest technology.


Taking ownership of AI means not just incorporating the technology but ensuring it creates value for business and society. Jason Davis, INSEAD Associate Professor of Entrepreneurship and Family Enterprise

Be mindful of ethical and moral boundaries. AI is a powerful tool that can be easily misused. Government regulations will be slow to come as the full potential of AI remains a mystery to most. In the meantime, err of the side of caution when taking decisions that could impact lives.


Corporate Publishing International.

urn:contentItem:5S3C-2VR1-JDG9-Y1RJ-00000-003 Quotes from Mark Zuckerberg's Senate Grilling that Should Concern You2018-04-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 Quotes from Mark Zuckerberg's Senate Grilling that Should Concern You

Washington: Independent Women’s Forum’s Association has issued the following news release:

 Facebook's CEO Mark Zuckerberg was on the hot seat yesterday as he testified before Congress about various issues from data privacy to consumer protections.

While Zuckerberg largely escaped unscathed, he made admissions that should be worrisome to anyone who values free speech and competition in the social media space.

Here are 3 quotes conservatives should be concerned about from Zuckerberg's testimony:

1. Zuckerberg admits that Silicon Valley is extremely leftist and there's bias against conservative views.

    'First, I understand where that concern is coming from, because Facebook in the tech industry are located in Silicon Valley, which is an extremely left-leaning place, and I -- this is actually a concern that I have and that I try to root out in the company, is making sure that we do not have any bias in the work that we do, and I think it is a fair concern that people would at least wonder about.'

Zuckerberg didn't explain how he seeks diversity of views among staff. He claims though that where political censorship arises, he tries to root it out but provided no specifics.  

This does nothing to quell concerns that the people who work for Facebook (from tech staff to reviewers) do not filter or censor conservative content. Just ask conservative commentators Diamond and Silk.

  2. New regulations from Congress will stifle competition and harm smaller startups.

    'I think part of the challenge with regulation in general is that when you add more rules that companies need to follow, that's something that a larger company like ours inherently just has the resources to go do, and that might just be harder for a smaller company getting started to be able to comply with'

This is an interesting admission. Facebook has said it welcomes Congress to create new regulations. However, that would be terrible for competition.  

Big tech companies like Facebook have lobbyists to help craft legislation in a way that gives them an advantage and the resources to comply with new regulations. Regulations would create new barriers to entry for startups though and could potentially put smaller competitors out of business.  

  3. Creating a safe environment may win out over openness to ideas.  

In response to Senator Ted Cruz's question about censorship, Zuckerberg concluded,

    'I am very committed to making sure that Facebook is a platform for all ideas.'  

Yet, later in response to Senator Mike Lee's questioning about censorship, he says,

    '… one of the things that is really important though is that in order to create a service where everyone has a voice, we also need to make sure that people aren't bullied, or -- or basically intimidated, or the environment feels unsafe for them.'

In this political environment, one person's postings may be 'triggering' to another. One could envision a situation where Facebook considers some content hate speech or unsafe simply because the reviewers don't agree with it. He says they don't ask about political affiliation, but also doesn't explain how the 'extremely left-leaning' perceptions of Silicon Valley don't impact their work.

As we've seen on college campuses today, students are quick to shut down opposing speakers and thought because they consider them offensive. College administrators have sided with students on limiting speech. What's to stop Facebook from following their lead?  

If there's one big takeaway from these exchanges, it's that we need greater competition in the social media space.  

As a private company, Facebook is well-entitled to set the rules for those who use their platforms. We can hope they will act objectively, but there are real examples that say otherwise.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VRM-6BJ1-DYTH-G4HX-00000-003 REASONS SENATOR ELIZABETH WARREN AND OTHERS ARE WRONG ABOUT TECH2019-03-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 REASONS SENATOR ELIZABETH WARREN AND OTHERS ARE WRONG ABOUT TECHStates News ServiceARLINGTON, VA

The following information was released by Americans for Prosperity (AFP):

Sen. Elizabeth Warren recently announced her proposal to have politicians micromanage or even break up tech companies.

If that doesn't sound like a good idea to you, it's because it's not:

America's biggest tech companies are controlling more and more of our digital lives. And they're using their size and power to make it harder for the next tech entrepreneur with the next big idea to break through and compete with themmeaning less options for us.

Elizabeth Warren (@ewarren) March 8, 2019

She elaborated on her proposal via Medium:

"I want to make sure that the next generation of great American tech companies can flourish. To do that, we need to stop this generation of big tech companies from throwing around their political power to shape the rules in their favor and throwing around their economic power to snuff out or buy up every potential competitor.

"That's why my administration will make big, structural changes to the tech sector to promote more competition including breaking up Amazon, Facebook, and Google."

Unfortunately, Warren is not the only one to offer a proposal like this. Many lawmakers on both sides of the aisle have the misinformed notion that politicized antitrust enforcement against tech companies will benefit consumers and entrepreneurs.

Here are three reasons why this approach won't work:

1. Breaking up tech companies won't stop political power from being "thrown around."

Antitrust laws, used in the way Sen. Warren and others suggest, do not stop political power from being "thrown around." Instead, they take regulatory power away from the proper enforcement agencies, such as the Federal Trade Commission, and give it to politicians further politicizing the industry.

2. Competition benefits consumers.

Antitrust laws are meant to address instances of collusion, price-fixing and other anti-competitive behavior. They're not meant to stop the competitive process.

Competition is what gave us the technology we enjoy today, and it will give us the products we'll be enjoying in the future. When consumers get to control demand, the supply is higher quality at more affordable prices.

3. Punishing successful companies won't help "the next generation of great American tech companies."

Google, Facebook and other companies became successful through competition, by meeting market demands with quality products. Punishing them removes the incentive to keep innovating. It also removes incentives for "the next generation of tech companies" to grow their businesses and become successful.

When businesses are not encouraged to innovate and grow, consumers end up missing out while tech companies from other countries move ahead of the United States as global industry leaders.

The bottom line is that government should not be in the business of picking winners and losers in the tech industry or any other industry.

America is home to some of the best and brightest minds. If left unburdened by heavy-handed government intrusion, the sky's the limit.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5FNK-4K11-F11P-X19C-00000-003 Reasons Solar and Wind Energy Will Take Over Our Power Grid Much Sooner Than You Think2015-04-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:05:45ZLexisNexis3 Reasons Solar and Wind Energy Will Take Over Our Power Grid Much Sooner Than You Think

Getting power from the wind and the sun no longer seems like a hippie fantasy: Elon Musk is betting that solar power will be so profitable it will help fund space travel, and big tech companies like Apple and Google are buying in, too. Today most homes and businesses are still powered by fossil fuels, but in just a few decades - maybe even as little as 15 years - most energy could be coming from renewable sources.


An enormous new survey of industry experts shows how fast things are moving. Recently, DNV GL, an international energy consulting company, asked 1,600 people who actually work in the field - at equipment manufacturers, power producers, utilities, policy-making agencies, energy retailers, regulators, and equity investment firms - about the future of renewables. One of the main questions: How quickly will renewables be generating 70 percent of the energy in the markets you work with?
Almost half of the survey respondents said they could see that happening by 2030. And almost all of them - about 80 percent - thought renewables would dominate by 2050.
Here's why they're optimistic about renewable energy:
Politicians are supporting it. "It is mainly a political question. It is clear that a renewables-based electricity system is technically and commercially possible, perhaps by the middle of this century, but only if backed up by political support," one German respondent told DNV GL. It's not a given, but, increasingly, politicians - even American conservatives - are onboard with the idea that the future of energy includes wind and solar power.
Energy storage is getting better. Two thirds of the DNV GL survey respondents chose energy storage as one of the top three technologies needed for renewables to work. (The other two: smarter grids and more money to build them.) And storage technologies are improving: This week, for example, Tesla is expected to announce that it's releasing a "home battery" that could help store power generated by rooftop solar panels. This is key to convincing people that renewable energy can be relied on - and making sure that's true.
Investment in renewable power is growing. Bloomberg New Energy Finance reported this week that in 2014 $270 billion was invested in renewable energy, about one fifth more than the year before. The largest portion of that money was going to projects in developing markets - Brazil, Indonesia, Chile, Mexico, Kenya, and China, where investments totaled $83.3 billion.
In other words, power, technology, and money are all aligning behind the same idea - that in the next few decades the way we power the world will change, dramatically. The only real question is how fast. 2015 Global Data Point.
